As for the money side of things, the first free aircraft (SU-25T) you get is nice, however I would strongly recommend purchasing a DLC such as the A-10C, even if it does seem overpriced. However if you want to get your money out of it, you need to be dedicated and patient as you learn certain aircraft.Warning: Steep learning curve for some aircraft - be prepared to spend a bit of time learning them.P.S. The reward will be worth it. Trust me :)

content:
er 26, 2015
												Probably the best modern flight sim on the market right now. The modelling of Air-to-Air missile performance is unfortunately quite simplistic (as are countermeasures), and high explosive bombs don't do much due to a lack of splash/fragmentation damage modelling, but the flight models and systems fidelity are superb. There's a reason DCS is a byword for high-fidelity simulation now.Don't come into this expecting your experience flying Warthunder or whatever to translate, though. You must have a joystick of some sort, preferably with a twist axis (unless you own a set of rudder pedals) and a throttle (unless you have a proper HOTAS throttle). Knowledge of basic aerodynamic concepts is important, as is the ability to dilligently monitor your aircraft's systems for potential problems, and the ability to learn the limits of each aircraft you buy.Luckily, you get two aircraft for free with the base game download. The Su-25T will teach you basic air to ground and missile avoidance techniques, while the TF-51 is basically the exact same aircraft as the paid P-51 module, minus the armament and a fuel tank in the fuselage that you'll leave empty most of the time anyway because it ♥♥♥♥s with aircraft performance. Get yourself a cheap stick and take some time to learn the free aircraft. If it tickles your fancy, buy whatever module interest you the most, and go from there.

I recommend to anybody willing to put some time into a game and learn it, and anybody who isn't satisfied with substandard flight simulators like x plane 10 and fsx, which are still great, but after you get your hands on Dcs, you'll never go back.

content:
, 2015
												(Notice, I play on the standalone DCS client don't let steam hours fool you) This game is my life, I've been playing it on the dcs standalone client for a year now. I own almost every module, no sim in history has ever came close to the detail of DCS. All negative comments about prices for modules or it being not user friendly is mute. This is a hardcore sim, if you love aviation then you will love this game. And it's slowly becoming the only true combat sim left for props.(Even though the ww2 aspect of the game is still very work in progress) IL-2 battle of stalingrad has went the wrong direction. IL-2 1946 is good, but the online community is dead, and the game has shown it's age. War thunder isn't even a flight sim, that games sim battles are a joke.The only other good option is IL-2 cliffs of dover with team fusion mods, it mixes hardcore elements of engine management, but is more forgiving than DCS.The module price in DCS is entirely justified by the quality done, if you can't see that, then you just don't understand what you're looking at. I recommend downloading the standalone client from the DCS website, you can benefit from both the steam sales and the companies own sales, which when they have them are HUGE discounts like 70% off.If you are interested in this game, give the Su-25T a try, (It's free) it's one of my favorite aircraft still. And then bump up to FC3, if you manage to overcome the initial complexity of working the radar, then when you buy a full, entirely simulated module like the A-10C or MiG-21 then it will make life easier. Though I NEVER recommend a beginner to pick up the a-10c, because even the more simplified FC3 aircraft are too much for a lot of people.

												DCS does what it does well, and for a free game it is great game for those looking to get into combat flight simulation.Getting more serious you will quickly find yourself craving more advanced cockpits and flight systems and that is where this game really ramps up with its DLC's.Enter: A10-C & UH-1H there are other great DLC but these are my two favorites featuring fully interactive cockpits and advanced flight controls.To put things into perspective, the operators manual for the A10-C is around 500+ pages of theory, procedures and checklists.If you just want the stuff you need-to-know there are cut down versions and plenty of videos online that cover everything from basic start-up to configuring the weapons systems, and using the flight management computer.I recommend grabbing the free game, get a feel for it and if you like what you try, grab the DLC's that interest you when they go on sale.There is a decent variety, just be sure to research the DLC's before you buy as some only have basic cockpits and systems while others are full simulations.

content:
5, 2014
												Top-notch simulation platform.  I've been flying DCS since 2011, started with the KA-50, and it was exactly what I have always wanted in a flight sim: the full complexity of operating the flight, navigation, and weapons systems of a modern attack helicopter.  A-10C?  Same experience;  Highly detailed, fully-simulated flight, navigation, communication, sensor, and weapon systems.  This sim doesn't hold your hand and you get out of it exactly what you put into it.For someone looking for a less-intense entrance into combat flight simulation, try DCS Flaming Cliffs 3.  The flight physics are a little more forgiving, and the systems complexity is greatly towned down, all while still maintaining realistic performance capabilities and excellent approximations of real-world detection capabilities and engagement envelopes.I only have one word of warning to give:  Once you get a taste of DCS, you'll never be satisfied with the limited aircraft "simulations" implemented in Battlefield, ARMA, HAWX, and similar games again.

												Hands down the best combat flight simulator on the market. This simulator combines stunning visuals with high fidelity aircraft simulations. content:
2, 2014
												Lets start with what you get out of this. Two planes (as of 2014: P51 trainer, Su25T Frogfoot) for free. The TF 51 (P51 trainer) is the more in depth of the two planes and is not for the feint of heart but should give you an idea of what the level of realism you should expect out of many of these DCS modules. Currently, DCS A10C, Blackshark 2, UH1 Huey, MI8MTV2, P51 and (Millitary) all have in depth flight dynamics and controlls with a fully interactive cockpit.Flaming Cliffs 3 is a module that comes with the F15C, MIG 29, Su27, Su33, Su25, and A10A. All of these aircraft have a slightly simplified flight model and do not have interactive cocpits. It should be noted though that this pack allows you to fly many different types of aircraft with the price of one module.Pros-Epic, Realistic, Online community is pretty awesome, quality online playersCons- Game engine can hold your system back (32 bit, runs on 2 cores, heavy on processor, only 1.5 gb ram), dated terraini detail, small community (though a quality one) Few aircraft choices, steam no longer supports serial numbers bought on DCS websight (steam serials are still supported by DCS standalone/nonsteam client though)Realistically speaking, this game doesnt offer a whole lot in terms of aircraft count like some of the competition out there. However, the aircraft are extremely well detailed and handle exceptionally realistically. In a dying age of flight sims, DCS is still going strong, with some of the most realistic aircraft modeling around, with a persistent community and invovled developers.

												I really enjoy DCS World in VR but it took me a lot of effort.  This isn't specific to VR: flight sims generally take a lot of set up time.  I have a HOTAS with pedals and for each plane you have to map everything.  Fortunately once you have all of this completed after many rounds of testing the experience is pretty awesome. 												DCS World is without doubt, my favorite flight simulator. It has been continuously expanding since I purchased it, and there are many highly detailed modules to purchase if you like this free base game. number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
r 2, 2016
												Recommend but Buyer Beware!So let me start with that I've spend some money on this title. A-10C, Combined Arms, Flaming Cliffs, and the Campaign pack for A-10c (so far). I used to play Falcon 4.0 all the time back in the day, and I'm probably around a dozen hours into DCS. First thing to know is that this is more like a system of games that all work together in one interface, this is why the DLC seems expensive. Next thing to know is that apparently the steam version of this title won't pass the multiplayer server checks and the recommended way to install is purchase and get your license keys then download and install from Eagle Dynamics website (wish I would have known would have saved me a lot of time and heartache). The next thing I want to talk about is the mission / campaign packs, especially the enemy within pick for A-10C. While the missions are well thought out, the voice acting and dialogue is amateurish. To the point that I am wondering if the pack was fan made, yet I  got charged $10 for it. I'm glad the missions are well thought out and briefings are detailed, but for the extra money on top of $50 for the A-10C ,I would have expected better recording quality and to be given a choice of starting locations. That's one of my disappointments with DCS. In Falcon4 you could choose ramp (cold) start, runway, or flying.  D.C.'s has some separate missions for this but campaign missions do not give a choice. You start wherever the designer wanted you too. Finally, multiplayer, and I mentioned at the start there's some kind of oddness with the steam download. Reddit seems to think installing a "pure" version from Eagle direct fixes it. I'll try that soonOverall I'm going to have to give this one a 8/10  would def have still purchased these games, but I wish that some of these known issues were out there front and center for purchasers.  So all that said, if you like flight simulations, you won't regret this. I recommend you have or plan to purchase a HOTAS   I play with 3 monitors trackir, and the x-56 HOTAS. If your a veteran of any of the Janes games from back in the day or Falcon4 like me then you will quickly feel at home

of cash and got the a10c warthog package ... thats deep as in setting waypoints , radio frequencies , setting chaff/flare dispersions etc etc ... but its bloody good fun , its also fully configurable with a good flight stick , i have an old hotas cougar that i want to mod for this , but generally im using a saitek x52 ... also excellent for elite dangerous , in addition i use it with an oculus dk2 and quite frankly this transforms this from a game to serious immersion territory , i can blat around in my a10 looking out over the wings and scan all around and the sheer scale of the aircraft is there ... your looking right back down 40 foot of fuselage to the tail over the huge turbofans , then you see the weapons draped under the wings however you set its loadout ... its there in full effect , i may as well just join the usaf as im already there just without the BS side of things :) another bird i had to get was the f15c , not as fully realised as the a10c but great fun , imagine full afterburner runs down the valleys keeping below 200 feet contrails streaming off the wings as you pull g then going vertical breaking through the clouds and looking down at a beautifully realised world ... when your machines good and you have the magic accessories this simulation really is as close to flying as you can get , i used to be an raf engineer and a part time glider pilot so i do understand whats being attempted here and you just cannot get better and its free!!!! , you just chip in when its given you a taster of what the real military do

content:
6, 2016
												[probably should mention that I own other DCS releases via stand alone (Black shark, Lock On II) and have recently expanded to Steam DCS ]What can I say... except for this has to be the best combat based flight simulator I have ever known (and I have been doing flight sims since F-16 Falcon on the ATARI 1040st [old fart alert]). I have seen a lot of combat sims come and go but none have ever been; as well put together, well thought out, realistic, had such a wide scope of details and interaction, nor had such an easy to use and stable online facility. There is also a wide array of single player and campaign missions (if you are not up for online interaction). I also have to give a big thumbs up to the constantly expanding and updating choice of vehichles (helicopters,tanks,planes) that are being made available to us. (standalone DCS already has a large back catalogue of vehichles and these will inevitably find their way into the steam stores at some stage however, in the meantime there is already a large selection of well known favourites available).I have to say that DCS world ticks all the box's, 1.flight charecteristics are amazing, 2.on board systems are detailed and relevant, 3.real world type damage that affects your planes abilities, 4.detailed weapons systems and management that actually get a bit of adrenaline pumping, 5.sound is fully imersive not to mention well balanced (no ear aches after prolongued play at full volume.)6.Graphics are jaw droppingly stupendous whether inside the cockpit or outside the plane graphical detail is heart stopping as is the landscape and objects/buildings/mountains/sea/clouds/sun (and I am only running NVIDIA 750ti ! I would love to see it on one of the latest generation GPU's the mind boggles...)I think the biggest tribute that I can pay to this simm is that: when I use air travel in the real world since DCS I know and can feel every thing the pilot is doing from take off to landing - though this can make for some nervous back seat driver feelings ("He's retracting those flaps a little early for my liking..." "I SAY ! STEWARDESS Could I have a word with the pilot please...^^ [air marshall raises eyebrowes] ;)Quite simply a 5 star release [disclaimer] this is not an arcade title ! YOU WILL need to know about flight and if you don't... Well DCS will teach you :)

												Some people say "oh no is so hard to learn all the stuff there", well they are missing the point here, it ain't a game, it's a sim. Sure, you can strap yourself into an f-15 and start killing bandits in a couple of hours, but the real pleasure, the real immersion, the real deal is in the learing and the feeling of locking a ground target with a maverick 7nm away (it may seem easy, but it ain't!) or dropping a CBU-105 and watch the earth burn or dodging a sam launch almost kissing the ground with your wing is an adrelanie rush hard to match in pc gaming.If you ain't a real life pilot (like me), well this is the next best thing.

ber 25, 2016
												DCS World is a "free to play" complex Flight Simulator.  It worked on Win 10, looked great, sounded great, played ok. You can fly an SU-25 "Frogfoot" Russian Ground Attack jet for Free.  It has a pretty detailed tutorial for that plane, broken up into sections and has an english voiceover.  The Frogfoot has Russian text and voices in the cockpit, so not easy to figure out by looking.  DCS also has a TF-51D Mustang Trainer plane for free but there is no tutorial for it, and it is a different flight model from the SU-25.  This flight simulator is Detailed and has a steep learning curve.  Has Instant Action, Create fast Missions, Missions, and Campaign.  Has multiplayer action also. You can fly with the keyboard and mouse. DCS World has Mission and Campaign editors so you could get missions from other players to play. It is also VR ready for Rift and Vive headsets. You can buy more planes, helicopters and campaigns for this game. Try it, if you like complex Flight simulators.For more info:What is DCS World?

												Invest in a H.O.T.A.S  (Hands on Throttle and Stick) I was considering the Saitek Pro Flight X56 Rhino, but lately I'm thinking the Thrustmaster Warthog is the ideal way to go as the reviews seem to suggest the durability of the warthog and craftsmanship are far supior than the cheaply made plastic Saiteks that keep getting negative feedback. If you are not keen on learning how to pilot a real aircraft this game may not be for you. All and all this is an epic military flight combat actuator.  Love the game!!!

, 2016
												D(L)CS world is (quite obviously) a flight simulator game, and a really great one.The game is hard, unforgiving, and requires a lot of practice to properly play, but once you figure out you're not supposed to end up with your nose in the ground it's a lot of fun.It is important to note that, while the game itself is free, it's almost impossible to play properly without using a good flight stick (the T-flight HOTAS X by thrustmaster is a pretty good choice if you don't want to spend a load of money on the more advanced choices like the Thrustmaster Warthog or the saitek X-52) which adds some costs to playing.DCS world comes free with the SU-25 frogfoot known by many from battlefield 4 and the TF51D (an unarmed version of the P51 Mustang used during WW2) but for different planes like the A10 you'll have to get the DLC.TL;DR it's great if you don't mind to put some effort and money into it.

ber 5, 2014
												In one sentence, this simulator is fatastically complex but simple enough for anyone to use (if they have the patience) and will provide hundreds of hours of gameplay.I'd definitely recommend using some sort of HOTAS setup to play the game. I'm using a Saitek X-52 Pro which works well, but even with all the button mapping provided with it, I still find myself using the keyboard quite a lot to use certain systems such as the autopilot and with things like starting up the aircraft. I'd also recommend looking into TrackIR or another headtracking system, which will give you the full feel of flying the aircraft.The training scenarios are very well thought out, especially for the SU-25T, which is included with the base game free of charge. The scenarios go through every possible system in the aircraft, from startup to navigation to landing to countermeasures.The missions are fun yet difficult, which will make you want to run through them again and again. I've only successfuly completed a handful in the 10+ hours I've spent playing them. I haven't spent any time in multiplayer yet, but from what I've read and watched on the internet, it will be even better than single player.If you like flying, I'd definetly recommend this. Plus, it's free ;)

												DCS World is an extremely fun game with a HUGE learning curve. Dont think that jsut becasue you can play War Thunder on simulation that you can just hop on and play this beast. In my opinion this IS the best simulation game on the market, and it's only going to get better with the release of 2.0.The biggest problem with this game is.... it's on Steam as well as its own source, which means that because Eagle Dynamics has an awesome sale does not mean Steam will. This is one of my biggest complaints! Seriously, ED (Eagle Dynamics) Have sales all the time and not once has steam had one.If you want to dive straight into this game without much knowledge of aviation, i highley suggust you buy some Flaming Cliffs add on. The aircraft do not have a fully clickable cockpit and they are fairly easy (i say that very loosly) to learn, however, expect to sit down about 5 hours to learn the basics.DCS World also gives us a more complex and real life feel with thir fully clickable cockpit systems, which will keep you on your toes when you have mid air emergencys such as bird strikes, hydraulic failures, etc.All in all you SHOULD play this game, it is the best sim on the market and its FREE! Seriously, even if you just play and use the free aircraft, they are still good aircraft! You will not find a game liek this out there.

content:
3, 2014
												I'll narrow this down to the good and the bad points about this game. (Updated 10/13/2015, shortly after graphics overhaul. [NOTE!] So far these upgrades are not shown in the above screenshots)The Good:-A large array of aircraft to fly(if you buy the moduls). Many of which are fully interactive, as in almost every switch and button can be flipped with the click of your mouse(you can rebind the keys as you see fit). The rest of the aircraft are more like simplifed simulations, not fully interactive but easier to learn. As far as I know, they handle realisticly.-Amazing graphics post update! The lighting, weather, and smoke effects are absurdly good, the ground now uses a bump map, meaning flat textures on the ground cast shadows, it really makes the terrain look a million times better. Basically it just looks better and even runs better.-Detailed single player campaigns for each and every aircraft, some single player campaigns very in their difficulty and legnth. For example, the A-10A's campaign features smaller scale misisons that don't require much time to complete. Where as the SU-25's campaign features much larger scale misisons that take much longer to complete(imagine after taking off from your airfield, you must fly for 20-30 minutes to the combat zone, then fly back to land when your mission is complete, Which I guess is more realistic).-Quick misson generators which allow you to practice with your aircarft before doing the campaigns.-One thing I really like is that you can choose your payload, each aircraft has a large variety of weaponry, and it is fun carefully choosing your payload according your mission objective. Variety is such a great thing, and variety is something this game has in large quantities.-The game is very well optimized now, it used to run like garbage even with incredeble hardware, but even after the graphics overhaul, the game runs a lot more smoothly than it did.-The load times have been vastly improved, it used to take 5 minutes to load anything up in this game, now its about 30 seconds to a minute to load. Any subsequent load time is around 15 seconds.Bare in mind my hardware specs are as follows:AMD 8-core 4.0 GHZR9 290 with 4GB of VRAM GDDR512GB 1600MHZ of RAMThe Bad:-expect a minor frame rate dips if our have mirrors and ground clutter active.-The game's training is hit or miss. The SU-25T(which you get for free) has training missions that are interactive. Then you have most of the Flaming cliffs 3 aircraft which have shoddy low res videos, that is out of sync with the sound and voice that is explaining everything. For the Mi-8, the game will only teach you how to turn it on, take off, and how to use the weapons, but it only tells you how to use the rockets, and 2 of the 3 types of gun pods, and doesn't teach you how to use bombs. Worst of all, it did not teach me how to land with the helicopter, which is harder than you may think. I crashed 40 times trying to figure out how to land properly. The game has a steep learning curve, and the training videos just makes an already hard to learn game even more inaccessible.-I find that the default controles are confusing and clunky. I basically had to completely setup and rebind the contols to something more comfortable. This took a lot of time, learning what each function did, then figuring out what my new layout should be. But when your done, your done and can enjoy the game. Keep in mind, you have to completely set up your controles for each indavidual vehicle!In conclusion:If I can add anything more to the review, I will. But overall, the game is great, and I highly reccomend it if you like flight simulators.

content:
17, 2014
												This is a fantastic simulator and game. I've spent many hours before the steam integration and have bought a flight stick, rudder pedals, and track ir because of this sim. If you love hardcore simulations that require patience and a little bit of study then this is for you.There aren't as many planes as other simulators, but what this simulator has over ALL others is quality. Both free modules (SU-25T "Frogfoot" & TF-51D "Mustang"), and the full modules (A-10C, Ka-50, Huey, Mi-8, P-51d and others) have very detailed flight models (physics) and fully interactive cockpits (for you button/switch lovers out there). You can fly all the modules this sim has to offer without a keyboard; as long as you have a mouse (to interact with the cockpit buttons/switches) and a flight stick/throttle for your HOTAS (hands on throttle and stick).Once you're comfortable in single player, you absolutely must try out multiplayer. I still remember my first couple experiences joining a multiplayer server in the A-10C (my favorite module so far). I joined their teamspeak channel and had a commander barking orders, ka-50's shouting rifle left and right, and the whole time I had an f-15c fly beside me who I thought was escorting me, but later I realised he was simply practicing his sortie/formation flight.The reward you feel for learning how to start, take off, fly/operate, then land an aircraft with this level of detail is an amazing experience. I warn you though, this is a simulation first and a game second so be prepared to put in time (around 10 hours) and effort towards the steep learning curve before you expect to have fun.

												I played the standalone version before playing the steam version so have more hours ingame than steam says.DCS World is a fantastic simulator, but please note the sim part of the name... this isn't a game you are going to load up and be flying around like Maverick within the first 2 minutes.  If you are willing to learn how the planes handle, learn what the limitations on each plane/weapon/vehicle are and practice, practice and more practice then DCS World is an amazing experience and game.The two planes that come with the free version are perfect for learning how to fly, the DLC modules bring in more challenging planes, maps and campaigns.The free map in the Black Sea region is huge, with more than enough land mass and sea area.Work is constantly being done on the sim aswell to keep the graphics and sound up to date, the new 2.0 update in testing at the moment is fantastic looking.The free single player campaign for the SU-25T is interesting, the tutorials are informative and the included mission editor is easy to use and gives you the ability to create very advanced missions and campaigns.  Multiplayer is also an amazing experience.I'ld recommend DCS World to anyone with an interest in flight from both modern and WWII eras, even if all you want to do is experience flying and not interested in combat.Nominated for the "I thought this game was cool before it won an award".. award.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 14
												After almost 90 hours in the game I can say this is truely a masterpiece in the making. Between the details and the amazing physics of the aircraft and flight. I will say if you want the full experience be sure to spend the money and get the Thrustmaster Warthog and MFG Crosswind pedals. I have paid for almost every aircraft available and I can say I do not regret a single one of them. The developers are always making it better and we will soon have the maps all in one version as well as the F18 and some much looked forward to WW2 aircraft, not that there isnt already enough of these amazing pieces of art but lets be honest there is no such thing as too many. Eagle Dynamics and all the aircraft developer companies have sucked me in and this is one of those games that you just wont regret. Everything was and is done right with this simulator. I keep calling it a game when in all honesty this is a pretty hardcore sim. Dont be scared when you hear hardcore though, you can make it whatever you want from relaxed to full on PVP combat. Many of these aircraft have all working buttons and knobs and require you to learn them inside and out which for many people is what we wanted in a sim this great. I have logged approx 45 hours in the A10C and have learned fully how to start it properly and taxi, how to trouble shoot problems and mitigate them in the air, How to drop bombs and use the weapons systems. Still much much more for me to learn and it will more than likely get hundreds of hours in the coming years alone. As for the mission editing it is fairly simple and with a few hours of learning you can make a very nice mission to your wants and needs. Again this simulator is fantastic and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking to get into a really good combat flight sim. 11/10 stars from me.

This game is the reason I got into flight simulation!After watching about 100 videos of people playing & learning to fly in DCS, I bought an X55 Rhino, Oculus Rift DK2, a leather drivers-seat from an old Subaru, mounted in a simple pine frame... 6 months later, and I think I've only scratched the surface of what this game can show me... number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 14, 2014
												EDIT: August 2015. DCS World has really grown on me. The simulation of airplanes by third parties is very well done, even with some of them still in beta. Eagle Dynamics also has a great idea shifting the burden of module development onto third parties for the most part, allowing them to commit more manpower to features, engine upgrades, and other things we have yet to learn about. The World War 2 planes, while few in number (P-51, BF-109K-4, and FW-190D-9) are well made, and a blast to fly. Integrates seamlessly with the Tacview software so you can review flights later on in a similar way Red Flag debriefings are handled.You will need a decent flight stick, one with throttle control. The learning curve is steep. If you want to get the full experience, expect to spend a few hours learning how to start your particular aircraft, operate it's various systems, how it handles, optimum turning speeds, and how to evade missiles. If you stick with it, the payoff is very worth it.

12, 2016
												Keen on reading pages after pages of manuals on radar systems, auto pilots, flight controlls and what not?Feel the urge to be shot down time after time again by enemy SAM stations and fighters?Do you have a desperate need to struggle with control mapping, button possitioning and horrible flying weather?If yes, continue reading. If no, move on.Because if you get past all of the earlier mentioned struggles and frustrations this simulator is fantastically rewarding!The feeling you get when you land your first bombing run spot on or shoot down your first enemy fighter with a AMRAM missile is absolutely superb! If you choose to put in the hours requiered, this simulator is absolutely breathtaking!Do keep in mind that this is a simulator much more than it is a game. Therefore it is not for those who is not willing to lay down the time and effort to get it just right. Furter more you ABSOLUTELY need a joystick and throttle. Preferably a seperated joystick, throttle and peddals. I use the Thrustmaster HOTAS Warthog setup along side the Saitek PRO rudder pedals, and this works wonderfully.I am curently awaiting my Oculus Rift and can not wait to pair it up with this sim!

content:
3
												I love this game because it's free to download and comes with a decent plane (The SU25T Frogfoot, ALSO CALLED THE CRATCH!) to show you the ropes about the game and guides you through everything without "babysitting" you like most games do. I like to think of the DCS "game" as a platform to access the modules and all of the modules are their own standalone game because the planes are so detailed and take a long time to master which would explain the pricing. Before you buy though, I would HIGHLY recommend you have a joystick, rudder pedals, AND a throttle quadrant as well as some sort of face track software/setup (FaceTrackNoIR, FaceTrackIR) and/or a multi monitor setup. These make the game much more enjoyable and makes it easier to focus on flying. Overall I think the developers have done a great job with this game and I would recommend it to all my friends looking to get into aerial combat simulation.

content:
2016
												An absolutely incredible simulator that's improving all the time. Be warned though, this is not for casual pilots (i.e. the War Thunder or Ace Combat crowd). It's not a pick-up-and-play game. This is an ultra realistic sim, and the learning curve is steep. You'll find that most of the negative reviews of this sim come from people who were expecting something far less realistic that could be played with an gamepad. A HOTAS joystick & throttle setup is pretty much essential. There are currently six different third party developers developing aircraft modules for DCSW, so there are always new aircraft from many different eras of aviation on the way. The future for DCSW is a bright one. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 25, 2016
												My Steam game time does not accuratly reperesent my actual time in game as most of it has been on the non Steam version of the game...     This game is amazing. The attention to detail is incredible. The ir missiles even lock on to the sun. If you want a game that gives you the feeling of really flying a millitary aircraft look no further. This game has it all... I can't even imagine playing this in VR.     This game is Very well optimized and can (in theory) be played with just a keyboard. I would highly recomend getting a joystick. It will greatly enhance your experience. You don't even need something exspensive either. I started with a Logiteck Attack 2. Then a friend swapped me for an Extreme 3D pro. Both are very cheep joysticks. The 3D pro is really all you need and it's like $30 on amazon. A true HOTAS is definatly the way to go though and after a lot of reaserch I will be getting a CH fighterstick, pedals and pro throttle. Hopefully I will have my DIY trackir hat built here soon and will no longer have to use a mouse to look around. The thing is though, even with the cheap control setup, the game is tons of fun. I would try the free Su25T first. Give the game a fair shot. I actually thought it was stupid at first and quit playing after like an hour. I came back a year later and started learning off youtube. It hit me. The game was incredible. From there on out I put in hundreds of hours. I got FC3 and had fun with the jets. Then I stepped up and got the Ka-50 and A-10C on sale. Very good purchases. Yes they take some time and willingness to learn but they really aren't that hard. The aircraft are setup logically. Once you learn the basics all the advanced stuff will click into place. Multiplayer is great and lots of fun. Finnaly... GIVE THE GAME AN HONIST TRY. ACTUALLY ATTEMPT TO LEARN THE SYSTEMS AND IMMERSE YOURSELF IN THE TECHNICALITY OF IT ALL. YOU WILL FALL IN LOVE AND A NEW TYPE OF GENRE WILL OPEN TO YOU!!!      ps. Set curves of like 20-30 on your axises. It will make flying a ton easier. also... Slow smooth motions. Slow is smooth, smooth is fast. :)

content:
er 3, 2015
												As far as old school simulator games go, there are still plenty of them going around, still alive by the modding community or it's general community at all. Among these was the pretty 'out of the blue' Lock On - Modern Air Combat, or as we called it back then - LOMAC. Amazing graphics, systems, physics, mechanics, it was a breeze of fresh air, no more we needed the piston planes simulation to sane it, we finally moved on to the modern battlefield.DCS World recaptures that sensation, and then amplifies it several times, and it's making it even bigger and better, with new modules, new mechanics, new looks and soon enough - a whole new engine, which will run smoothly and beautifully. Even if the modules are a bit on the pricey, i can't recommend it enough, buy just ONE module, pick one, MiG-21, A-10C, Flaming Cliffs 3, whatever you choose, you'll feel you're buying something WORTH. This is where we, lovers of speed, smoke, and fire, can reunite and rejoice.

You have a fullblown simulator of most aircrafts, but not only that.Their systems, Problems and Funstuff are also reallisticly simulated. Ever wounder what the F*CK a R27ET is? I GOT TANGO ON MY TAIL!". Working together is beyond satisfaction. It is rewarding, it shows how grim and dangerous modern combat is. It lets you fear that one misstake you are going to make and see your friends in ruin.The best part is that you can try it for free, the su25 is plenty fun. Try it out, it wont hurt you nor your wallet.

content:
16, 2015
												 If you are looking for a cerebral experience, this is it. Great niche community ages ranging from youngins' to actual pilots or crew chiefs online. So many videos for training, helpful forums and a huge update coming out soon 1.5 (hopefully!)   Didn't know anything about flying before this game, but after many sessions and beers, it grew on me. I can start the A10C manually in under 5 minutes now, including INS warmup. Highly recommended if you want a fun game that isn't mindless drull.   There are two types of cockpit layouts basically. Some aircraft modules have fully interactive cockpits. Others, have limited cockpits that utilyze hot keys. You get the modules that you want, and if you don't know or can't decide, watch a few videos online. Hell, the game is free and comes with two complimentary aircraft.   I have setup face tracking for this game. I built a three IR LED system for under $7, and there is a multitude of freeware out there to use. So stupid amazing. The game is also very mod friendly and allows rather easy export of .lua files to utilyze if you are building a sim pit. I have a few panels that I have already made.    As you can see, you can go easy and arcadey mode, or fully immersed experience. Enjoy!

												A great simulator, however, not for the feint of heart. If you are looking for an Ace Combat style game, look elsewhere. The learning curve on this game is large. Whereas most games have a 1-3 hour learning curve to be proficient, 2-3 weeks is to be expected here. The effort is, however, greatly rewarded. With time and effort, and a pinch of anger management, you get a truly immersive experience. As far as DLC is concerned, that is where this game truly shows its colors. They can be a bit pricey, ranging from $10 to $40. It is well worth the cost, and the game is in no way diminished by purchasing a single or select few items as opposed to all. All in all, I cannot recommend this game enough for real world pilots and enthusiasts alike.

er 30, 2016
												I'm happy to say that after over 2 months of trying to get help from support that this saga is finally over.  In that time period there was never a single suggestion made to fix the problem, nothing but questions that had already been answered by the information I provided.  After telling me to wait for a refund weeks later I was then told that was impossible since I bought it through Steam.  Yet another fail by tech support as after making it clear I wasn't just going to give up and let them keep my $40, $40 that I got nothing for - no game play and no support - finally I was issued a refund via Steam.  No apologies for the complete lack of support I got, no explination, just a short message that they were emailing Steam.  Even in doing the right thing they showed how completely and totally incompentent their support system isNow that I can finally put this train werck of a game/company behind me anyone have a suggestion as to what I can spend my $40 on???  I'm sure it'll be more fun than the crap that DCS put me through.------------------------Never have I had such a horrible experience with tech support.  After 2 months of delays and not a single suggestion to try (only a few questions) and after being told to wait so they could process a refund the case was closed.  I then opened a new case and posted the story on their forums - the subject of "Worst support I've ever received" was changed to "VR Issues" and my account was banned for a month.  No message, I've read all forum rules and see nothing I've violated.  I didn't dox or otherwise call out anyone by name.  Just banned and can't even reply to any threads on the matter.I hope they do the right thing and issue me a refund so I can remove this review and we can simply part ways.  Until then I hope that at least one person will read this review and move on to some other game.  While different I play a lot of Elite Dangerous and as a space/flight sim it has similarities (VR and HOTAS support), skip this, I'll buy you a copy and teach you how to play it instead!!!!Original Review--------------------------After spending *many* hours trying to get DCS to run smoothly I'm finally giving up.  No matter what I do or how I play I get these little stutters every 3-4 seconds.  It's like the whole game pauses for an instant then is back to normal.  Doesn't matter if it's on 3 monitors or 1.  VR or not.  High settings or Low.  Stutter stutter stutter.  My PC is rather powerful, Core i7 4770k 3.5Ghz, 32 GB RAM, 250GB Samsung EVO SSD, Zotac GTX 1080.  I play many other demanding standarnd and VR games that all run butter smooth.  I'm rather disappointed as the experience in VR is rather fantastic but the constant stuter makes it an unplayable barf fest.  I'll just go back to enjoying Elite Dangerous which is incredible and performs beautifully.

er 17, 2014
												One of the very few sims out there, and a great one at that.Insanely detailed, accurate flight and systems modelling, you'll feel like you're flying the real thing.Of note is the Helicopter flight dynamics, which are currently unmatched in their realism.More and more planes are being added, but as of June 11th, 2015, available planes ( each purchased separately, apart from the TF-51D and the Su-25T, which are free with the game ) :_A-10 A Warthog_MiG 29 A, G and S Fulcrum _Su-27 Flanker_Su-33 Sea Flanker_F-15C Eagle_Su-25A Frogfoot(These planes are part of Flaming Cliffs 3, and have no clickable cockpits, and reduced fidelity systems modelling )(These modules are "DCS Level" which means the highest attainable standards, with the exception of Top Secret systems ( most notably IFF ) )_MiG 21 Fishbed_P-51D Mustang_Mi-8 Hip_Ka-50 Black Shark_UH-1H Huey _F-86F Sabre_BAE Hawk_Fw190 D9_BF109 K4_C-101 Aviojet ( EB and CC version, latter is still WIP as of now ) _MiG 15bis Fagot_A-10C WarthogIn Summary, if you like spending hours learning to fly and operate military planes, this is the sim for you. It is however not recommended as a game, and the combined price of all modules is very high. I recommend you buy modules when they are on sale ( happening every 2 or 3 months ).One of my most played games.

With time and effort, and a pinch of anger management, you get a truly immersive experience. As far as DLC is concerned, that is where this game truly shows its colors. They can be a bit pricey, ranging from $10 to $40. It is well worth the cost, and the game is in no way diminished by purchasing a single or select few items as opposed to all. All in all, I cannot recommend this game enough for real world pilots and enthusiasts alike.

er 17, 2014
												One of the very few sims out there, and a great one at that.Insanely detailed, accurate flight and systems modelling, you'll feel like you're flying the real thing.Of note is the Helicopter flight dynamics, which are currently unmatched in their realism.More and more planes are being added, but as of June 11th, 2015, available planes ( each purchased separately, apart from the TF-51D and the Su-25T, which are free with the game ) :_A-10 A Warthog_MiG 29 A, G and S Fulcrum _Su-27 Flanker_Su-33 Sea Flanker_F-15C Eagle_Su-25A Frogfoot(These planes are part of Flaming Cliffs 3, and have no clickable cockpits, and reduced fidelity systems modelling )(These modules are "DCS Level" which means the highest attainable standards, with the exception of Top Secret systems ( most notably IFF ) )_MiG 21 Fishbed_P-51D Mustang_Mi-8 Hip_Ka-50 Black Shark_UH-1H Huey _F-86F Sabre_BAE Hawk_Fw190 D9_BF109 K4_C-101 Aviojet ( EB and CC version, latter is still WIP as of now ) _MiG 15bis Fagot_A-10C WarthogIn Summary, if you like spending hours learning to fly and operate military planes, this is the sim for you. It is however not recommended as a game, and the combined price of all modules is very high. I recommend you buy modules when they are on sale ( happening every 2 or 3 months ).One of my most played games.

ry 13, 2015
												Best flight sim on the market. It's really realistic, so it may be quite hard for new players. Don't download it if you expect something like War Thunder with F-16. If you really like having a less - arcade, realistic experience, and you have some patience, you will learn really fast.Devs put a lot of time and effort in every module (which have clickable cockpits), so there are only few planes at the moment, but there are multiple dev groups. There are 2 types of modules (DLCs): ---  Very realistic, with clickable cockpits (everything is funcinal just like in real-life): A-10C, KA-50, UH-1H, MI-8, MIG-21, P-51, BF-109, Fw 190D-9, F-86, C-101 Aviojet, Hawk T.1A - some of them are in Beta (as for now), but even those have a lot of features already (A-10C, KA-50 and UH-1 are 100% complete), also there should be F-15 and F-18 soon--- Other modules are from Flaming Cliffs 3 which is like more arcade version of DCS, but has DCS engine and absolutely compatible. Those FC3 planes are not clickable, so they have less realistic features (you don't have to press 40 buttons to start up, just push 4 buttons on keyboard, wait 10 sec and it's on), but it's still enjoyable especially for new players. DCS is free but it has only 2 free modules - SU25-T and TF-51D. SU-25 doesn't have clickable cockpit, but it still has many features - weapons, autopilot, radar and stuff, and TF-51D is fully clickable (but doesn't have any guns)Some DLCs have manuals, but even if they don't, just go on Youtube or Google. You can also use manuals for real aircraft, those have a lot of pages but they worth it.Multiplayer has a lot of servers but only few have more than 10 players.The downsides of the game - those are quite random but common.- FPS - i'm running the game with Radeon HD7950 (overlocked, equal to GTX770), sometimes getting 25-30 fps on low-medium settings - when on airfield, near some big town, or in multiplayer. But usually it's around 50, getting better when im flying and there are less cities around - may go higher than 60, like 90-120. But, some people say they having 50+ fps on ultra high. Those maybe Radeon drivers, or my luck- Bad synchronization with Steam - overlay doesn't work randomly or it doesn't count hours of playing (5 hours instead of 50)-Haven't noticed any gamebreaking bugs yet.Hope my review was useful, sorry for some misspells

content:
6, 2016
												I have been playing this game since it first came out.  I recently moved it over to STEAM for simplicity but at the end of the day this is uniquely one of the greatest simulation software pieces I have ever owned. EVER.  Since Falcon 4.0 (which blew away even Falcon 3.0) I have been in search of this kind of greatness. It has a learning curve that could only be called a "learning cliff" (stolen from EvE Online) but once you learn to fly The Hog you'll never be able to go into a crappy flight model again.  It is unforgiving in that you will need to do your homework to both fly and fight; but the reward is huge. I've now invested... most literally thousands of dollars on everything from the HOTAS Wartgog, the Obutto game seat, a SimPit, button boxes, iPad software, Track IR... and I am still looking at what other cool things I can add to further push the reality of this sim.What can I say you should do?  Get a good HOTAS (The Warthog natively works so well), get a TrackIR, and a big monitor.  Then start down the road of full enjoyment with this.  If you love flying, pick this up and XPlane 10, most of the hardware tends to lend itself to a lot of flying!  But I will warn you, once you get past that furst few hours of learning to fly, you'll probably end up wondering where you can carve more time out of your day to get into the pit.

content:
1, 2016
												I got DCS with the Flaming Cliffs and MIG-21BIS addon.It's true that it takes ages for them to design and release an aircraft, but the result is a very detailed cockpit and after a while a balanced aicraft that performs like you expect.The learning curve is very steep, if you never got into military flight sims and have no ♥♥♥♥ing clue of tactics and strategies you will struggle alot. You will find yourself reading up on ECM-Jammers, Flares, Chaff, what you do when you get an enemy missile launch on you, etc. You will spend hours digging and searching for every bit of information. You will go and buy a decnt HOTAS flight stick aswell as TrackIR cause this game is so awesome.You will map keys after each fight cause you noticed: ♥♥♥♥, it would be quiet advantageous to have this or that mapped on my stick! After playing this game you think differently about aircraft. Flew the SU-27 and did a pugachevs cobra once? Then you feel awesome as ♥♥♥♥. You will know how dangerous missiles are because the process is not just "Ohh let me pop some flares / chaff". You know you need to judge if its a Heatseeker or not and plan your defence on that.You will begin to start to think like a fighter pilot. Sit in a large aircraft traveling the world: "Ohh that was a nice takeoff / That was a hard landing, glad the pilot nailed it". Why do you think like that? The pesky airline pilots calling themselves "captain" are laughable. You know better than them how hard it is to fly a plane and what they do is nothing compared to that.10 / 10 after you play this game and someone would show you what buttons to press in your favourite aircraft you could fly it if you don't black out cause you're a gawddamn nerd that hates doing sports like me.

content:
12, 2014
												This is a definite buy/download if you can invest some time and like complex games or simulations (or blowing stuff up). I was quite sceptic at the beginning but I still had my old joystick here and I thought: hey, it's free so let's try it. Flight simulators were always an alien genre to me but now I can't get enough. I bought the A-10C addition shortly after that, and was overwhelmed by its complexity (vanilla was already quite good).Do not expect to lift off in less than 10 minutes. There is so much to do that you basically need to switch to the manual for every button or switch. Sometimes the manual isn't enough so you search the forums for useful information and somehow you end up reading military documents about the maths behind escaping a missile. At least 50% of my time with this game included doing research about some specific systems and I haven't even tried them all and don't even fully understand those which I use frequently. But you know what? I have been playing this game straight for a week, my sleeping cycle is deeply disturbed (I go to sleep at 5 A.M and get up at 9 or 12) because it is so addicting. I also tried the included mission editor and it seems to have a whole lot of potential.There are a few downsides however: the campaign may feel quite realistic with much action going on, but it is missing some kind of story. Even though it is not as bad as  ARMA communications, the voices feel a bit robotic and monotone. I wish the AI would do some smalltalk even if it is maybe not appropriate.Another point is the map: it is huge, for sure, but after a while it becomes a bit boring. Not that it matters much, but I like looking out of the window when flying to the combat zone. However, along with the new EDGE engine, ED will bring out a new map afaik.I had a few performance issues during huge bomb dropoffs (dropping my entire payload) but all in all, it performs excellently for having so many units running at once.Also you need to be very, very patient. For example the navigation system on the A-10C needs around 4 minutes to start up and you really shouldn't move the vehicle until it is done. My best time from starting the game and taking off on the runway lies around 7 minutes and I repeat it for every single mission. And more often than not I get blown up before even dropping my first bomb. It can get quite frustrating.In conclusion, this is one of the most hardcore simulations I have ever touched and I will be touching it for some more time. it is deeply addicting and will lead you into buying more stuff so you can fight better oder try out new things (maybe a HOTAS instead of that old joystick). For those who have played other flight sims, don't wait. This download is well worth your time and the Su-25T model is really easy to fly in comparison to the A-10C. It has a few flaws, but you can easily ignore them while still trying what that button does... hey let's just push i- WHAAAaaaaaaaaa......I'd gladly give it a 9/10 and that one point missing is for taking my sleep

content:
, 2014
												It's the best flight sim in the world. There simply is no substitute for CAS aircraft simulation. Falcon BMS provides a great F16 simulator. However, for everything else DCS is superior in every way. The A10C is the most faithfully recreated aircraft in their line up. But you can still have a great time flying the Russian black shark. The feeling you get when you successfully start an aircraft from a cold start is amazing. You also get to try out the SU25 for free (and the modern version for a price). it's not nearly as fun as the A10C, but it still lets you learn the basic weapon systems. It's VERY IMPORTANT to remember that the A10 is NOT the same as the A10C. the A10 will get you a more forgiving "arcadey" aircraft (but still more realistic then something like say ace combat or battlefield, think of the old Jane's flight sims level). the A10C will give you the real deal. The A10C package does include basic tutorials for things like learning how to properly fly/start/land/engage in an A10. But things like working with JTAC will not be explained. So quite a bit of reading is required on your part.

												WOW! This flight sim is over the top! I just can't get enough of it. The flight models are superior to every other flight sim I have tried. The details of the planes and cockpits are beautiful and having the freedom to click every button and switch, just adds to the experience. The cockpit layouts are spot on. Every item is where it should be as in real life. Flight mechanics are awesome as well. As real as it gets for a flight sim! Learning how to fly these aircraft can be a challenge, but most modules have "training exercises" to help you figure out what to do. Flight manuals can also be found online, on steam or at the DCS website. There are also traning videos on Youtube. I personally enjoy the A10-C Warthog. The experience in the A10-C is intense and it is such a spectacular flight model. The other aircraft are awesome as well. Flying the Russian birds and hearing the Russian radio chat is great! There are so many positive things to say about this title I would be here all day, but I would rather be gunning down soldiers or blowing stuff up on the awesome missions or campaign! See you in the skies, pilots!

content:
8, 2015
												FSX gone military. You have to love flight, (which I do,) and you have to know the controls/general similarities among all aircraft (which I also know). This ain't War Thunder or IL2 Sturmovik or any of those types of games. This is a full-out sim.I, as a frequent FSX pilot and aircraft enthusiast, love this game. But, on the other hand, if you're one of those guys who wants to hop in a cockpit with all of the systems already running and not worrying about how to find the flaps switches, then DO. NOT. GET. THIS. GAME. Get War Thunder instead. It's still fun. Trust me. I play it.Let's focus on the main point. This game is absolutely free. Yes, I know, only two free aircraft. But they're incredibly realistic, plus it's not like real military pilots switch from aircraft to aircraft, just as I love flying the Boeing 737-800 in FSX. It's the plane I fly the most, and the same logic goes for this game. You get involved in one aircraft, you learn about it, you cry over the lost hours of your life spent learning how to fly it, and then you love it. You don't go 5 minutes into an SU-25 and then decide "meh. I'm more in the mood for flying a MiG. Maybe after that I'll also fly a Mustang." To sum it up, it's free, and it's either you love it or you hate it.

content:
ry 28
												If you are at all interested in combat flight simulators (both ww2 and modern combat era) I'd highly recommend trying this game. The fact that it's free and includes a sweet jet for free (the SU-25 Frogfoot) is enough to at least give it a try. It definitely has a learning curve, however, so don't expect to be doing any cool ♥♥♥♥ within the first hour or so. Lots of keyboard commands for micro management of all systems like engines, weapons, radar systems etc etc. So don't expect to be getting into some "arcadey" dogfights right after installing. This is more for the die-hard flight sim fans that enjoy a slow paced, realistic simulation of flying combat planes. It will take time and dedication to learn how to fly these planes and utilize them in combat.I love the map size it's huge and tons of ♥♥♥♥ to do online it has a very open world feel so you can do whatever (PvP/PvE) and not feel like you have to participate in any particular thing if you don't want to. The community is quite friendly and helpful so you'll almost always find someone to talk to and help walk you through figuring ♥♥♥♥ out. All in all, if you're into combat flight sims, this is definitely a game to try out. It's free, has a helpful community, and it has a great way of allowing you to play and enjoy the game at your own pace without feeling rushed or like you're falling behind in anyway. Personally I feel it's the best mix of realism and enjoyment (not too hard, not too easy, and very fun) in any flight simulator I've played so far so I'd give it a 10/10

content:
5, 2016
												Disclaimer: I have hundreds and perhaps into the thousand hour territory on DCS World. I play on DCS Standalone so my Steam hours aren't exactly reliable.DCS World is a study level sim excluding the FC3 aircraft. This is many, many steps above series such as Ace Combat or HAWX. Even the FC3 aircraft are above the level of simulation you might see in something such as War Thunder sim battles. The level of enjoyment you have will correlate to both how into flight sims you are and how much effort you are willing to put into learning your aircraft(s). Do not expect to hop into multiplayer and shoot down a number of people on day 1. It's just not going to happen. However, if you stick with it, you'll find an amazing community that has done a tremendous amount of work towards turning this into  one of the best simulators out there (on par with Falcon BMS 4.33). Communities such as the buddyspike team create an atmosphere where teamwork and large scale coordination is not only encouraged, but crucial. In both single player campaigns and multiplayer full scale warfare, this sim is as real as it gets outside of flying the actual plane. I can't even begin to describe the feeling of being deep in the AO and behind enemy lines running all sorts of operations or having a GCI coordinate a large scale air war. The amount of focus and effort required is large, and the learning curve is quite steep. If you've got what it takes, I highly recommend this sim. The modules are without a doubt expensive, but as they are as close as a civilian can get to flying these aircraft, the price is more than just. Considering that you can spend hundreds of hours in each one of these aircraft, the cost isn't as bad as you'd initially expect. Plus, there's a ton of sales all the time on DCS Standalone. I rarely pay full price for any module.

												The free SU-25T is so fun, that I still play it despite owning all the other DCS Modules.  The attention to detail on all the planes is great, but the A-10C, Ka-50, UH-1 Huey, and the P-51 Mustang with their fully clickable and 6DOF (six degree of freedom, with TrackIR) cockpits are unreal. content:
4, 2014
												This game is one of the best free to plays I have ever played. Its the kind of game that you can play for hours and still not learn everything there is. I have played 26 hours at the time of this review and still haven't used the autopilot, weapon systems, and much more. Everytime I play this I seem to learn something I didn't know before. It does take a while to get a hang of and I wouldn't recommend it to anybody who gives up easily because you do need to crash a lot in order to get a hang of everything. It is a game that seems to reward those who put in the time to learn how to fly specific planes because it has a ton of keyboard bindings, some a necessity some a conveniance. The planes you get in the free version do a good job at showing two sides of piloting. The TF-51D is a plane that in the game requires some learning in order to know how to just start it since it has an eight step proccess to start the engine. Once you get the TF-51D in the air it seems to be an easy plane to learn because it doesn't have a very high top speed and therefore has less you can mess up with in things such as landing. The SU-25T is completely different because it makes everything on the ground easy but once you are in the air you can break your wings off if you turn too sharp (which I know from experience). The community from what I have experienced is very friendly and I don't hesitate to ask them questions because they are helpful for the most part, aside from the LCtrl+e+e+e jokes every once in a while. Overall this game is great, it is a game I would willingly buy which makes it even better that it is free. If you would like a game that can teach you something while you learn, this would be a great game to try.

content:
y 27, 2015
												DCS happen to be "the" flight sim developers right now, and their numerous flyable aircraft offer a high degree of detail and realism that is unsurpassed in the military flight sim genre.  The Ka-50 Black Shark helicopter, and the A-10 C Warthog for example, are two highly detailed aircraft that will take most budding pilots weeks to get to grips with, let alone master.  Fortunately, DCS World provides a more immediate introduction to the flying module without the extremely high learning curve in say the A-10C, and with a reasonable joy stick, you'll be flying fairly quickly.  There are several aircraft to pilot, including the F15, Su27, Su33, Mig 29S, and the Su25.  The flight modeling is exceptional and level of world detail extremely high.  I would recommend having a fairly high end PC to really enjoy the physics and visuals in the game - it is processor heavy.  Ideally, you probably want to invest in a joy-stick and possibly flight pedals down the road, if you really want to immerse yourself in the art of combat flying.   I've been playing for several weeks now getting to grips with the Su-27, and it's been suitably challenging, offering a lot return playability.  Cranked up to full realism, and this quickly becomes a very, very challenging simulator - which of course is where a lot of the joy comes from.  Be prepated to be truly immersed in the flight environment.

content:
23, 2016
												Preface: I'm experienced on flight sims, but I'm also a normal person, with no $1000 setups, no endless hours and neurons to waste, nor a fixation on any single title or genre. I played DCS probably a couple hundred hours or more in his non-steam releases especially A10C (the hours counter is bugged anyway atm).I recommend the free plane (su-25T) and the Flaming Cliffs DLC, as all planes in there use classic pc-friendly control scheme and are thus fairly easy to pick up for any average flight simmer. I'd rate the difficulty in Flaming Cliffs models at probably somewhat easier than original/vanilla Falcon4 (but the overall game environment is MUCH tougher).Game is rough around the edges, it's doable with a fair amount of patience but you will have systematic crashes and various unexplained "wtf" situations to figure out...There will be a lot of key remapping and note-taking.MP is full of well-designed scenarios and it's a good thing it's populated, given the absence of dynamic campaign in solo. I advise caution in delving into 'professional' models of modern platforms -like A10C, Mig21- nless you are *really* hardcore  (note: I thought I was).Choppers are fun and the avionics aren't too complex, even a Black Shark is full of strane russian trinkets but still eons easier than a cold war/modern era plane. Mostly choppers are hard to control well without a serious setup, require lots of patience because of the slowness and general tactics involved, and die far too easily, so you might still have fun but not be very effective.Overall I feel like saying that planes with advanced avionics simulation like A10C are hardly worth the effort imho, in the sense that the intricacies of the electronic systems totally overshadow the 'game' aspect. If you really want to see the more advanced simulation you should start with the F86 or Mig15 maybe. Or as I said, best to forget it and go with the Flaming Cliffs models.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
6
												An amazing sim with a powerful flight model, that is aging well. constant updates and 3rd party development keeps this game relevant for years now. however graphics optiumization has taken a serious backseat. i have a powerful rig with GTX 1080 and I cant even get it to run smooth in VR, 2D monitor is buttery smooth. Mission and campaign  editor is a powerful and complex tool making replayability a grand adventure. however due to the fact that aircraft may come from different developers, the quality for each aircraft varies. I have since bought the mig-21BIS, FC3, A-10, and combined arms addon packs on sale and I have come to realize the sheer amount of quality research done on the flight model and avionics to make this game shine. Going to military aviation conventions and bookstores, I have bought books from the 60s 70s 80s and 90s on some of these aircraft and the information is valid and relevant. The free aircraft (SU-25T) is a great aircraft to learn in and is still my go-to primary plane. it teaches you to be conservative with the controls and gives wide range of targets and attack methods to hit. its also well armored and surprisingly fast in a level dive run-in, so you can take some flak before having to RTB. DCS World is the best all-around modern combat flight sim in my opinion at this time, any improvements they make are just additions to this fact. I have tons of fun in IL-2 Battle of Stalingrad, and im not sure how the WW2 aircraft in DCS compare in realism to that as I do not own those modules. When speaking to my uncle (Who is a SU-25 Pilot) he explained that the engine control is reasonably simplified and automated ingame as most people dont have enough buttons on their keyboard and flight stick for that task, but besides this fact, it is modeled very close to the real thing, and a person practicing procedure in DCS could learn to fly the aircraft fairly quickly with a training program. The sim in general has an issue with scale. speeds and distance are scaled down and vehicle models scaled up to create and illusion of a larger playable space and save on processing power. He noticed it during takeoff as passing runway objects appeared to be moving too slowly relative to aircraft speed, and it is a subtle factor to the game to improve performance

ry 16, 2014
												For those who do not want to read an essay here, I have three valid point for people who could be interested in this simulation game.1. It's free to try.2. It's the best war plane simulator out at the moment as my feelings go.3. Each "DLC" is a whole game on it's own. It's not only added content in the manner of new plane, but it is intended as full game with campaing. All this is then integrated in one world for Multiplayer purposes.And now for those whou would want to read a bit more. :)It's so damn complex it blows my mind. It simulates the whole plane, each part of the machine is simulated in some form. It depends on what dlc you buy but for example the A-10C or KA-50 (and others too) have fully clickable cockpits and simulated on board computers. You can do everything a real pilot could do. With combination of really powefull mission editor anything is possible.You get whole campaings for selected planes and even in the free to play basic package you can run a campain with SU-25 plane. Now when you combine this with multiplayer and really superb community, you get a package that can keep you entertained for years. Mercenary mission with your friends or with you "clan" are only the top of the iceberg here.I have only one con here, the game is really demanding. You will NEED to have a 64bit machine and highend CPU/GPU to really enjoy high details. This will maybe be solved when a new engine will be released (it's planed for this year) but I wouldn't put high hopes for this. Its mainly focused on adding DX11 support.

content:
, 2015
												DCS World is, quite simply, the combat flight simulator that I've been waiting for. From the get-go there's one thing that I have to make absolutely clear: *This simulator is FUN!If you are an aircraft enthusiast and always had the dream to fly, then this is your best bet - that is, if you are not a real pilot or if becoming one is not an option. The only things you won't feel when you strap yourself into a DCS World cockpit, are the G-forces. The instructional training missions are on-point and helpful, the missions challenging and fun, the learning curve steep and frustrating at times, the manuals as thick as a medical encyclopedia - but you know what, it's the package. I remember the days when I played Jane's USNF 97 and Microsoft Combat Flight Simulator, which were games that I couldn't get enough of. DCS World has replaced them with the same amount of, or even more, fun.Simply brilliant.

content:
ry 16, 2016
												DCS World is an unapolegetically realistic Combat Aircraft Sim. You know how you have all those dials, gauges, switches and stuff in your typical aircraft cockpit? Well in DCS they all actually mean something and have ramifications as to how your aircraft performs.I can't stress this point enough, DCS (Which stands for "Digital Combat Simulator") is a SIMULATOR. That means that it's less focused on traditional game design paradigms and more concerned with realism. Sure it's probably not 100% Realistic, I've never piloted an aircraft in my life (and never will due to medical reasons), so a real pilot would probably be able to pick at things. That's fine, to my understanding it's about as close as you can get with modern technology.Yes this means a steep learning curve, ESPECIALLY due to the fact that not all aircraft operate the same. They have different start-up procedures, binded to different keys (or differently placed buttons), different avionics systems, and different controls.I know that this is a turn off to most of you, but I'm giving it a thumbs up for one simple reasonIf you are just plain curious it's free!Yeah yeah there's a buttload of DLC which has most of the content, but If you try it and it's not your thing, no harm no foul, but if you take the time to actually play it, slowly learn how to operate your aircraft, and have the patience, focus, and willingness to try, try again, you are in for a treat!Because once you get used to it, flying these things is really freakin AWESOME! These things FEEL like jets, and to a degree, you are crossing miles of (virtual) landscape in pretty much a blink of an eye, and delivering a projectile at even greater distances in some cases with avionic-assisted precision! Just an awesome feeling I think!Also for those who like attention to detail, some of the DLC planes (including a free one you get, a T51 Prop-plane) actually have the ability to click on individual buttons/turn dials and cranks alongside the binded keypresses. Which is really neat!*Just remember though you are buying planes for an extra simulation experience, it's more of a self-study than anything unless of course you need to round out roles because I'm sure Ground attack/CAS isn't going to be what everyone wants to do in a Combat aircraft sim.

												Original Review ~20 hours logged:""""""I would love nothing more then to give this game a good review, it is by far the most realistic flight sim i have played. That being siad its also a huge disapointment dlc wise. I have bought both the f-15c and a-10c (4.99$ and 9.99$ i think) dlcs and expected to get a full flight expeirience with each craft. the f-15c has no training missions which makes the craft absolutly worthless to me. the A-10 has a wonderful training program but they skimped out on any decent content campaing wise. thats only 2 of the 250$ worth of dlc and if they expect me to pay 49.99$ for a single plane they better ace the cheaper ones to show me what im getting. because of this the A-10 will be the only dlc ship i ever fly and my review went from one of praisal to one of disapiontment."""""Reached 69 hours and got my first MP kill followed imediatly by my second... Followed imediatly by me spinning out of control due to excessive dive and improper nose trim adjustments.This Game is amazing. My review was at i time when i thought i understanded this game. I've logged a decent amount of time since then and fell in love with the Su27, and this flight simulator is absolutly fantastic. My advice is not to make rash judgments, take the time to learn everything properly and Multiplayer makes the game ( Although you will be blown up a lot ). Ask questions If you need help, obviously not everyone is willing to help but this game seems to have a fairly positive community.Also you can find a flight manual for the f-15 in the file location and there are plenty of tutorials on the web.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
												Probably the best and most realistic flight simulator on the market today. And on top of that you get to blow stuff up! What else could you ask for?-Modules I have tried out-A-10C: Most thorough flight simulation I have ever flown. From what I can tell all of the flight systems, computers, and avionics are operated exactly how they would be in real life and also have the same advantages, faults, and limitations. That being said starting it up from a cold start is always rewarding (If you do not mess something up along the way) but also very braintwisting. I have a much higher level of respect for the pilots who fly them for not just smashing their heads into a pulp trying to get the plane started up. The flight dynamics are exceptional also, and it's intricate weapon systems are very fun to blow up Russian tanks with.UH-1H Huey: I have flown hundreds of flight simulators, but they were all with fixed winged aircraft. I could not find a better way to learn the art of helicoptering from this jem. The Huey is a historical legend for it's service during the vietnam war among others, and its later civilian services that still continue to this day. It sure flys like a legend too, you will not find many complicated computer systems you have to spend days learning about in it. Starting it up is simply turning the right combination of knobs and switches. Flying it is not real challenge after spending enough time to get used to it. You will learn to hover it and land in the most obscure places possible. It's flight dynamics like any other DCS title is exceptional. From the basic increase in lift as the helicopter gains horizontal velocity to the more uncommon stalling. The developers really show pride in their work as many other aerodynamic effects are modelled in such as rotors breaking due to a high RPM and negative G environment. The weapon systems are really fun to mess around with, there is really not much to them apart from shooting a minigun in the direction of your enemies and watching the carnage.Flaming Cliffs 3: A great module for the less experienced flight simmers or casual player. Instead of focusing on a single high quality aircraft the developers worked on a great variety of more mediocre modelled aircraft. There are no interactable cockpits here besides closing the canopy. Apart from that, the planes are still modelled well for the status quo of a flight simulation. The F-15 included however has a very well modelled aerodynamics system that blows all the others in this module out of the water. Even though this module is much lower quality than the other titles, it is still very fun. And lets face it, cheaper too for the amount of content and variety it has.I would reccomend for more veteran flight simulators to stay away from this module as most of the planes are not very well modelled and some are just dumbed down versions of other aircraft in the simulation like the A-10A and SU-25.The F-15 is the plane that makes the module worth it, and as it is now only 10$ I reccomend just buying that instead of paying $50 on Flaming cliffs 3. The only reason I got it was it was on sale and was the same price of the F-15 at the time, so it just made more sense to buy all of Flaming cliffs 3 instead of just one aircraft included in it that was the same price as it. Free aircraft:TF-51: The TF-51 is a real fun plane for aerobatics if that is your cup to tea. It has a pretty good flight model and has a fully clickable and interactable cockpit, its flight and internal systems are just as well modelled.SU-25T: Although it is not exceptionally well modelled with the fact it does not have an interactable cockpit, the SU-25T is one of the most combat effective ground attack planes provided in the simulation. You will have plenty hours of free fun learning the plane's systems, flight characteristics and employing it's weapon systems successfully. A great plane to introduce new pilots or players to the simulation.
