content:
6, 2014
												There'a a lot to say about this game. Look for the TL;DR at the end.This is probably the best deal on Steam. You don't have to spend a dime and you get access to an increadiable game. It's a full blown simulator, so expect a decent learning curve, especially with the weapons and navigation systems, but the game comes with a full compliment of interactive tutorials. After a good Saturday of playing, I had a good handle on everything and could freely enjoy playing. Mastering those skills is something else entirely, but of course, part of the fun.Re-playability, for me this is probably the most important part of any game and for me, this game offers a lot of replayability, if your willing to put in some work. The game comes with a handful of missions, but the Mission Edditor allows you to create your own custom missions and it's a POWERFUL tool. Create a vast and complex mission or even campaign or a simple scenario for you to practice your shooting skills. If your savy, you can even use Lua to write your own scripts and really add complexity.You don't need additional hardware for this game, but a good flight-stick at the minimum will make the game a lot more fun. If you have some cash and want to get a HOTAS stick and throttle, that's probably the best way to go. I don't have one and don't plan on getting one and I'm quite happy with that. Certain actions take me a bit longer, because I have to hit CTL-ALT something.  TL;DR - If you're looking for a combat flight simulator, this is the best I know of. If you have some money to spend I highly recomend the A10-C add-on. Expect a decent learning curve with a high pay off. A lot of re-playability with the custom mission editor. Maybe get a flight stick.10/10

												This game is an absolute gem. DCS World is a true flight simulator that even incorporates modern AA and AG combat into it. I am absolutely positive that this is the best flight simulator made to date. Just to address one concern of others. When you download DCS, you recieve a free aircraft, the Su-25T (Frogfoot). It's a very capable aircraft and enjoyable to fly. Where people get upset is that there are lots of DLC module aircraft that you have to pay for. The thing people don't understand is that this game is made by a business and they have to make money. When they spend 3 years developing a module, a 2.99 price tag isn't going to cut it. The fact that they sell some of these for $10, especially with the low playerbase of the game is astounding. Instead of complaining that you have to pay for these aircraft, praise them for being so generous.EDIT: For some reason DCS only counts the time in game on my steam account as the time the game is launching. I really have at this time (30/09/16) approximately 230 hours.

3, 2013
												This is the most awesome thing in the world since Fire&Beer and whoever doesn't play this 24/7 has NEVER lived!edit 23.12.2014; Been playing DCS:World now since 09/2012 and there hardly goes by a week I don't take time to fly for a few hours. Make no mistake, this is a flightsimulator at heart, no GAME. Even if there are planes with a very low learning curve, for the full 'DCS experience' you should read or watch the manual/tutorials.edit 01.07.2016: Still at it! With 1.5 & 2.0 we have lot's of new stuff. Best 2.0 feature: Collidable tree's!There are planes/helis for casuals, hardcore flightsim-nerds and of course newbies. If you want to fly the A-10C and still find new things to learn after two years (~600 pages manual) or a Su-25T where you can learn how to fly & kill stuff in a few minutes with a tutorial is completly up to you.WW2 era is progressing at a quick pace, at the time of writing there are two very active WW2 dedicated servers with fun& sometimes realistic scenarios although the allys are quite a little outgunned at the current point with only the P-51D Mustang, but that will change very soon.Don't expect any balancing to spare your feelings, if an engine is more powerful IRL it will be in DCS.I own all the current released DCS modules and promise you every full DCS module + FC3 is worth the money. No starforce DRM, buggy patch or delay development can destroy the immense fun I got out of this. This sim is the next  best experience to flying a plane RL we can get on the civillian market right now. X-plane/FSX/P3D have just inferior flight models and I have yet so see anyone of those do a comfortable 6dof-friendly & clickable cockpit like in DCS.Pro-Tip: You can fly the Su-25T & TF-51D for free! The latter is nearly exactly the same as the P-51D Mustang, only unarmed. With the Mustang you can really see what this Sim is about, Su-25T look what FC3 may be like.

DCS World: a great flying simulator, and it's FREE!I'll write down a fast review, because I haven't got much time to spend on this.I'm playing this game as my main flight sim. Is the game fun at the beginning? No, not really. At the start it was just frustrating. The commands are hard to learn, and not intuitive. I couldn't turn on the plane.Then I got it, and started playing. I liked it. So I went to the store and bought a flying joystick.Logitech Attack 3(fun fact: I bought it for CHF 5.- (€5 circa) NEW!)I bought the F-15C Eagle too. (not fun fact: I bought it and the same day it went 50% off. ♥♥♥♥ my life)It's a really good game, the physics are really realistic and playing with friends is fun! Formation flying and dogfights are really satisfying.Pros and consPros:-good graphics-good planes-good dedicated servers and community-physics are good!Cons:-learning curve-a really hard flight sim, don't bother downloading if you're not looking over to spend time on learning how to fly a planeFinal rating:Well, I rate it 9/10 'cause it's a really good sim overall.AS I SAID, let go of this game if you're not gonna invest time in learning it. It's not install&shoot. NOT. AN ARCADE. GAME.I've seen negative reviews saying "too realistic". Dumbasses downloading a flight SIMULATOR and whining about it being what it is supposed to be.EDIT 29/04/2016: The "switching windows" bug is gone, and now the interface is really smooth and good!

												THIS IS FROM A HELI PILOT'S POINT OF VIEW (In-game not a real heli pilot)Pros-Amazing detail in every vehicle-Flight physics and damage are on point-Community is pretty decent-Sound FX are great-Lots of campaigns, missions, and tutorials-Sling loading is fun-Multi-crew is slowly being implemented-DCS 2.0 will be out with a new, more detailed mapCons-DCS 2.0 probably won't come out within the next 5 years-Map has no detail and pyramid shaped mountains-Vehicles that are simulated are not very popular and there are few options between helicopters-Popular servers do not incoporate helicopters very well and I usually have to fly for 10-40 minutes just to find out there is a SAM site guarding the AO-Very few people fly helicopters and on PVP you are mostly against Su-27s and F-15s constantly-Not very moddable with the new verified signatures update.This game is great for plane pilots.For heli pilots, there are not many games out there that have as good a helicopter simulation as this. Take On: Helicopters is pointless because Arma 3 exists with AFM, and stuff like FSX or X-Plane have about the same cons that this does. So you are pretty much stuck with this for now.This will be recommended because there are far more plane pilots than heli pilots.

content:
ry 1, 2015
												Best combat sim on the market in my opinion. The Complexity, shear reality and authenticity of each module is astonishing. IF you're a die hard fan of flight/combat sims or just a casual player looking for a flight sim then this is a game for you! The free modules which are Su-25 &  TF-51 are great modules to get a taste of what DCS World is all about. Eagle Dynamics are making a great job on improving the game and making it even more realistic. There still somethings that need tweaking but the game itself is amazing and I would recommend to anyone. Its possible to fly using a keyboard and mouse but I strongly recommend even a cheap joystick as the analog input is needed for flying and dodging missiles. Overall the game is 9/10 and cant wait for DCSW2 to come out. #We want the F/A-18!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 20, 2014
												I started playing this game back in November of 2003 when it was called Lock-On: Modern Air Combat and was released on PC-DVD by Ubisoft.  I continued with the Flaming Cliffs, and Flaming Cliffs 2 Expansions, and now finally in Steam as DCS World with all these wonderful modules (read: individual aircraft simulators).  Mind you, this is no arcade shoot-em-up style game:  this is a STUDY SIM.  And each module/DLC/airplane is a detailed flight simulator of that airplane.  You will spend hours just figuring out how to start the plane, taxi, take-off; let alone navigate and use the weapons systems.  You will also REQUIRE at a minimum, a joystick.  I'm using a CH Products Fighter Stick, Pro-Throttle, and Pro-pedals (which I highly recommend.)  These days a REAL flight sim game is hard to come by:  DCS  has filled the niche wonderfully and exceptionally with these simulators.  When the zombie apocalypse happens, you can jump from DCS to the real versions of these planes with no problems.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 17, 2014
												Barring the AI, this is a brilliant flight sim. I see in all the negative reviews complaints about complex controls.. This is not Arma, where planes and helicopters model less than a quarter of the systems they have; this is a realistic combat flight sim. If you don't have a joystick you are not going to enjoy this sim. Note that even "game" mode is more realistic than Arma. To those who think this is just another free to play money grab.. Each module has about the same amount of time put into them as each complete Battlefield game.. (maybe not Combined Arms)Pros:- Extremely detailed systems modelling for the A-10C, P51 and Ka-50 (although controls can be frustrating without a TrackIR)- Very high detail graphics-wise- Free updates add to the sim as well as fix things (the engine is also updated sometimes for more functionality)- Very large range of vehicles and aircraft to fight againstCons:- Poor AI (without extensive scripting in the editor). They overuse afterburner and run out of fuel when they reach their target, MiG-31s enter dogfights rather than outrun their enemies, ground units can see through forests and buildings, helicopter gunships fly high when attacking and almost never hover etc.- Some aircraft have lower resolution textures that look ugly, but that is expected from a high detail, realistic flight sim- Virtually unplayable without a joystick, but that is once again expected.

7, 2014
												It is an amazing simulator, probably the best one out there. I bought the Flaming Cliffs 3 Addon so far and it is tons of joy, it is quite a bit challenging to learn the ropes if you are new to simulators (like I am) but once you get into it, you'll have a lot of fun.   Russian and American planes both have different avionics, making them feel different (and as such you have to learn to use both separately). Still trying to get used to the radar, but locking on and firing with missiles is piece of cake once you learn how to (watching the tutorials for both russians and americans twice did the trick for me).So, all in all, if you are looking for a very realistic simulator, definitely give this one a shot because the basic game is free and has the Su-25 and the TF-51 in it, which by themselves already offer a lot of fun, and from there you can decide whether you want to get into the game more.P.S. If you ever see me in a multiplayer game (I still have yet to play it), go easy on me. I'll most likely be an easy target for you anyways :P

												I had not plaied any flight sim games in some years, until last week. My freind was talking about DCS, and being free I figured Id give it a try. Hands down the best flight sim I have ever plaied, and it has brought back the love I have for avaition. 10/10I will say  however it is not for thoses who want the casual flying of a jumbo jet, or island hopper. Even the simplified planes require a good amount of practice with, and tweaking of controls to fly well, and operate well in combat. The "full" sim planes are a blast to figure out and when you get it right you feel like you acomplished something. The "simple" planes give you the ability to get into combat faster since you do not have to spend all your time just geting an engine started, or maintaining settings while in flight. If you are looking for a real combat flight sim, this is it. "It's just plane awesome!"

												Hugely detailed sim, can't stress it enough how much I'm in love with the DCS series of aircraft simulators thus far. The advanced flight model aircraft with fully functional cockpits are about as close to the real thing as you can get without actual military sim equipment. And ED along with other 3rd party devs are continually releasing new aircraft to build more possibilities for the game and it's multiplayer. And having this single platform bring all previous and upcoming sims into one environment is genius.And the base platform comes with two free sims, a Su-25T (rivals A-10 Warthog with it's massive arsenal, it's powerful and easily capable to be able to hop right into multiplayer without spending a dime) and a trainer version of the P-51D, for aerobatic fun.Note that this pretty much expects you to have a joystick, don't expect to play on a keyboard, unless you buy the Combined Arms pack that lets you take control of vehicles and fight it out on the ground.Absolutely no reason not to give it a try. Unless you hate planes or something. But what kind of monstrous, awful person actually hates planes

content:
ber 18, 2014
												I climb into the pilot seat of my Bell UH-1.  After following start up procedures and insuring everything is in working order I slowly raise the collective.  My bird starts to steadily lift off the ground though it wants to spin to the right.  I rudder till it is straightened out and continue to ascend, wobbly.  I leave the confines of the airfield I took off from and make my way to a nearby city, making long sweeping turns as I go.  This isn't so bad I think to myself.  I've seen videos of people trying to fly and hardly getting off the ground, I guess ArmA3's advanced flight model actually payed of!  After a flying around the city for a few minutes, turn my attention back to the airport.  Is that a C-130 I see?  Surely it is.  I have to go get a closer look.  I make a beeline for the airport, my instrument panel shaking violently as I proceed at dangerous speeds.  As I approach the plane, seeing that it is indeed a C-130, I spot a C-17.  I've got to check that out too, I pull back on my stick and to the left, lower the collective a bit and rudder into the most beautiful turn I've ever seen.  Across the flight line I spot a 707 chasis.  I wonder if that is a KC-135!  I take off in it's direction.  As I approach from the front I realise that I am going to have to make a near 180 in order see the rear of the aircraft to see if it is infact a KC-135.  I pull the stick hard to the right, but I was coming in too fast and forgot to correct my collective.  Panic sets in as I watch the altimeter rapidly tick lower and lower.  Now is not my time.  I hammer up on the collective and continue to bring the helicopter around.  An alarm goes off, I assume it to be alerting me to the rapidly approaching ground, no such luck.  The helicopter lurches upward at an alarming rate, the alarm doesn't stop.  Suddenly I hear a loud *CLUNK*  I think to my self, "What the hell was that?"  I then realise that it suddenly got a lot quieter, the sound of blades cutting through the air no longer a constant droning.  Infact it isn't their at all.  Alarmed I look around and spot my blades hurdling through the air.  I quickly apologize to my stoic faced co-pilot, he seems to have resigned to our fate.  Nonetheless I punch at the controls to no avail.  In a short moment we slam into the tarmac, exploding in a fireball of glory behind the aircraft I was so eager to check out.  I never found out if it was a KC-135 or not. 10/10

content:
ber 16, 2014
												If you're looking for one of the best military flight sims made to date, look no further.The A-10c Warthog flight model and cockpit / controls is one of the most comprehensive and true to life models I've ever seen outside of MSFS. Coupled with some third party voice activation and a decent HOTAS joystick, you really can't go wrong with DCS and the A-10c DLC. The helicopter DLC (namely the Huey) from what I hear are also brain-numbingly well done.Expect some reading! I ended up printing out the 700 pg manual, memorizing two different bands of radio channels, and of course teaching myself the startup and setup procedures. And I'm still learning! Some people call this the epitome of "study-sims" but to me, that's like calling a good book the epitome of "wordy-books." Don't be silly.Even though the DLC packs I've gotten have added up to be the most expensive title in my library, even getting them on sale, I've gotten much more than I ever expected, with more to come having only really stretched my wings in the A-10c. Certainly not purchases I regret. But not a flight-sim for those with a short attention span. Startup procedure is a solid 10 minute process. :)With only a keyboard and mouse, expect a slightly more substantial difficulty curve

												If you are keen on flight sims then DCS World is a must have.  I'm interested in WW2 aviation and enjoy the DCS experience.  If you are new to flight sims and want to try a "propellor" sim I would recommend "il2 Battle of Stalingrad" before trying DCS.  DCS would probably be too over-whelming for the first time flight sim player.  BOS would give a more satisfying experience.But for the flight sim grognard there is a lot to like about DCS.  Fully clickable cockpits, very nice flight model, competitive AI and the option of jets.  Plus DCS WW2 is coming soon.Good support on the DCS forums.

content:
y 11, 2015
												This game is simply amazing. I found this game browsing Steam and decided to give it a try. Given that the SU-25T module is free, I figured that it would be low quality and very limited in its playability. The complete opposite is true! The plane proved a pleasure to fly and I thoroughly enjoyed the challenge offered in mastering the plane. The first time I was able to take off from an airfield, find a tank convoy, attack it successfully, and return to base, I was sold. The game sucked me in and I knew I had to buy some new modules. I decided on the A-10A, F-15C, and SU-27 modules. The planes are beautifully modeled and each one offers a unique approach to their specific role. Although the learning curve is steep (especially steep for the A-10C, I hear), the reward of mastering an aircraft is unmatchable in comparison to any other game I've ever played. The game offers fantastic gameplay for those who are into heavy ground-pounding aircraft like the A-10 or SU-25 and for those of us who dream of being the Top Gun and dominating the sky. I haven't tried any of the helicopter modules, but they're next on my list. Those looking for a challenging game and are military jet fans should definitely try this game. 10/10!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 13, 2015
												Great flight sim that involves combat aircraft. If you're curious about flying and if you'd like something like this DCS being free is a great point to give it a shot. You're only able to fly the SU-25T which is a clunky russian jet, and the TF-51D which is an unarmed version of the P-51. Any other aircraft you'll find yourself having to pay for them to be able to fly; but they are very much so worth the money. They painstakingly recreate these aircraft with all of the bells and whistles of the real deal, down to the weapon loadouts, the systems on the aircraft and even the instrument panels are accurate to the real deal and if you so choose you can click the switches and simulate pressing them yourself rather than pressing a keybind on your keyboard.Controllers/joysticks are easy to configure and the mission editor lets you configure custom missions to fly as well as the multiplayer is fun. If flying is your thing, or could be your thing definatly give DCS a shot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 11, 2015
												This game is simply amazing. I found this game browsing Steam and decided to give it a try. Given that the SU-25T module is free, I figured that it would be low quality and very limited in its playability. The complete opposite is true! The plane proved a pleasure to fly and I thoroughly enjoyed the challenge offered in mastering the plane. The first time I was able to take off from an airfield, find a tank convoy, attack it successfully, and return to base, I was sold. The game sucked me in and I knew I had to buy some new modules. I decided on the A-10A, F-15C, and SU-27 modules. The planes are beautifully modeled and each one offers a unique approach to their specific role. Although the learning curve is steep (especially steep for the A-10C, I hear), the reward of mastering an aircraft is unmatchable in comparison to any other game I've ever played. The game offers fantastic gameplay for those who are into heavy ground-pounding aircraft like the A-10 or SU-25 and for those of us who dream of being the Top Gun and dominating the sky. I haven't tried any of the helicopter modules, but they're next on my list. Those looking for a challenging game and are military jet fans should definitely try this game. 10/10!

content:
ry 27, 2015
												This is THE BEST combat sim I've ever played. The realism is outstanding and it's fun to play over and over. The amount of variables that can be controlled is almost overwhelming at first, but in a good way. The whole setup allows for a whole lot of freedom to plan an attack or a counter attack or to pretty much fight the enemy anyway you want. I really can't wait to see what they have coming in the future. It's hard to find a game that I truly get excited about these days but this is definitely one of them. They even have aerial refueling. Man is it hard but that's part of the fun. The only issue I have, and it's not really about the game design itself, is that I wish there were more American combat aircraft. I hope it's in the works but I'd really like to fly an AH-64 on a sortie in the Middle East or fly an F-22 and bomb the crap out of ISIS. There really is almost an unlimited amount of expansion as the creators didn't box themselves in with this game. The game is totally outstanding, even for Russians. :) :) (BTW that's why there are so many Russian aircraft)

content:
ry 24, 2015
												Amazing game a must have, If you love Fighter simulators then your in for a treat, it has a big learning curve to it, but all in good time and practice you become a great fighter10/10Edit:That was my past review I thought well now Ive gotten the gyst of it let re-review it. inb4 long ♥♥♥ read hope it helpsFirstly you do not need to have a HOTAS Joystick and Throttle or rudder pedals, its a bit more difficult but its still do able. The First im gonna say 50+ Hours I played with my Logitech Extreme 3D Pro $40 Joystick (I live in Australia), I played Su-25T, FC3 and Partially A-10C. I played them all comfortably the only thing that was needed was to remember more keybindings etc for the A-10c and Su-25T, FC3 all the important stuff was able to be bound to my joystick regardless the point is, for a free simulator that has a amazing engine and crazy realism to it all you need is $40 for a joystick and any extra money for modules and you can play. I bought the HOTAS Warthog around 60 hours into the game still dont have rudder pedals but thats fine I just use the 'Z' and 'X' keys thats it, if you love Military aircraft and you plan on enlisting one day then install this game, do it you wont regret it, if you love a challenge this is the game for you. To lay it out ill put some pros and cons below.Pros:- The SU-25T and PF-51 Mustang are Free- The best Military Aviation Simulator on the market- Aircraft are being added all the time for example Leatherneck Sims is working on a F-14 Tomcat model which is gonna be amazing- All eras of Aircraft from 40's all the way to current.- FC3 is more of a easier version but still in relation to the realism flight.- Plenty of Single Player missions and servers to play on.- Graphics are beautiful on this game as well as the sound.- Performance is good even in MP, I have a 8 year old GPU and a Quad core CPU and with come custom settings and Mirrors off I get in SP 40-60 FPS and in MP 30-40 FPS- If you buy it from the website or steam you can still play with eachotherCons:- It has a big learning curve- There are only a few tutorial missions for standalone modules, there is no Tutorials on FC3, F-86F, Hawk only to name a few.- SP missions do tend to bug out sometimes not all the time- In the same sense that it is cheap it is also expensive with each module going for about $40+- not all of the modules are on Steam, the ones on the DCS website are available on there for a while before it gets released on Steam. For example 14 out of the 17 available modules are available on Steam not including terrains or campaigns.- You need Rudder pedals for rotary aircraft I tried and wasn't able to fly without themSo in short this is a great simulator it has its cons but its so worth it for the pros of the game. Some advice if you are thinking about spending $500 on a HOTAS Warthog, ask your self this are you going to make Simming a hobby or is it going to sit on your desk and collect dust? Simming is a expensive hobby so unless your going to use it dont bother. If you want to try the game out use a cheap joystick like the 3D Pro, if you are going to play moderately grab yourself a X55 Rhino it has HOTAS Functionality and so I have heard its a good joystick, if you know you are going to sim a fair bit at least 3-4 times a week and put hours into the game get the HOTAS Warthog and some rudderpedals. Also if you see the modules F-15C, SU-27, SU-25 and A-10A for DCS dont bother they are $10 each they are all included in Flamming Cliffs 3 Module as well as the MIG-29A, MIG-29S and SU-33.So do I recommend the game to everyone? Yes give it a try you may like itFor aviation enthusiasts? Why haven't you already installed thisFor people who want to make simming a hobby? Go buy a HOTAS and modules to your likingI absolutely love this Simiulator and if you love Military Aircraft you will too, I hoped this long ♥♥♥ essay helped in your desicion.

If you don't have a flightstick or hands on throttle and stick you're going to have a bad time.

content:
y 30, 2016
												The worst thing about this game are the prices for the more in-depth cockpits, but most likely if you spend that much on them in the first place, it will be very worth it. DCS is nothing short of amazing. It feels awesome to fly the planes, the learning curve is there, but after a few days, it's all down and good. The planes have weight to them, and even the simplest of maneuvers and procedures can't be done by just jumping in and acting like you know what you're doing.If you aren't an experienced pilot, no worries. You can start with circling airfields and landing at others, move onto some strafing runs, go to bombings, SEAD, and by then, you'll probably have purchased FC3.Speaking of FC3, researching the expansion will likely tell you that you need the others, which isn't true anymore. It's an awesome expansion for learning to fly. FC3 is basically the bridge between the SU-25 and aircraft like the A-10C.It's a great game, and it's free to start off. If you like aircraft, whether it be FSX, ArmA, IL-2, or any other simulator, you will like this game.*Also, even though the photos show the SU-24, and some other planes, you cannot fly any planes that aren't A). the SU-25T, or B). listed in a DLC.*

content:
8
												 This review is many years in the making. I got involved and DCS about five years ago, but just with in the last year I have gotten more serious in learning some of the aircraft I have purchased over the years.   It's takes time and patience to learn each individual aircraft.   You need to study manuals, and you need to do your own research.  I started with the A-10C but have become extremely attached to the BF109 K4 lately and spend most of my time dogfighting online.  This is by far the best sim out there, nothing compares.  Xplane 11 is a clunker compared to this game. (I own Xplane 11) I have purchased several modules on steam but I play the game via the most up to date version off of the DCS website and I also use 2.0 with the Nevada map.  Looking forward to the new Normandy map!  Love this game, well worth the $500 or so I have invested so far plus justified a 970 GTX purchase a couple years ago.  See you in the skies! (I'll be in your 6)

content:
y 16, 2016
												If your into SERIOUS combat flight sims you will LOVE this game!  That said...if you like the "pick up and play" style of flying games you will not like this.  You actually have to spend time with the manual and watching youtube vids to learn the systems of these aircraft to be effective in DCS.  It will take some time and effort....but theirs a huge feeling of satisfaction once you can command these aircraft effectively.  You feel like your in command of a real military war machine with all of its systems at your finger tips. There is a  game mode setting in DCS that simplifies everything to "pick up and play" style of simplicity. It makes the flight physics alot less realistic...and basically turns DCS into "Ace Combat" style of gameplay. Keep in mind every online multiplayer server thats worth anything (full of player)s to play competitvely DO NOT ALLOW "game mode". If your not playing DCS in full simulation mode then you will find it very difficult to play online.  All the most popular multiplayer servers ban "game mode"....even some of the more trivial game options are not allowed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 10, 2016
												If you're a fan of Flight Simulation and you're looking for a thrilling combat experience, then DCS is the one you should choose. No other software would be able to provide you more realism and get you closer to what a fighter pilot really feels aboard those powerful machines. The numerous controls are hard to handle at first and I recommend you to read the flight manuals to familiarize yourself with the numerous instruments available to you. The tutorials are too basic and don't allow you to put in practice what you've just learned as they are just a bunch of videos. So the flight manuals are really not a luxury you should pass. Dont worry they are free but It would take some hours to read it all as it's pretty consistent.On a personal note I'm not pushing for gender equality but if you could add a female voice for the pilot I would gladly appreciate that. ;)

content:
y 21, 2015
												The two free aircraft that you get are very fun to fly, and decent to introduce the game to you. This is a combat flight simulator with a command element to give the ground units more realism. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in aviation, or flying aircraft. This game does have a slightly steep learning curve, but that is countered by video tutorials available at the main menu of the game. I highly recommend that you visit the developers website, and download a copy of the checklist for the aircraft that you wish to fly. Then print it out and keep it handy, or download it to a tablet. The graphics are not bad for a flight simulator, but are not cutting edge. The multiplayer is not bad, but depends on the server and its mission. Most multiplayer missions are community developed, and not all aircraft are available in every mission. Their is also no in game VoIP feature, so downloading Teamspeak is a must for voice communication. All and all a good game, but better if you pick it up during a sale.

content:
er 8, 2016
												If you want a flight sim that isn't as dull and dated as FSX or Xplane  then DCS is for you. However, all that glistens is not gold as they say... DCS has fantastic visuals and great professional flight models and the 3D modelling on the plans is superlative. However, many planes are still in early access and have been for quite some time and as such are not featured on Steam. Also as many of r/hoggit users would tell you, DCS may as well stand for 'Delayed Combat Simulator'  as the standard wait time for a two week release is about a year. That's not to say that there isn't enough to be getting on with just understand that if you're stoked for a new module you've heard about you may have to maintain that enthusiasm for a loooong time before you actually get your hands on the stick. Also, despite the base game being free, everything else is very expensive. The Navada Test Range and the new modules will make a big hole in your bank account unless you pick stuff up on sale. Two high fidelity planes in DCS will spank you for more than £60. So be aware, that while it's a great flight sim, it's a money hole. Do I recommend it? Hell yes. It's superb and enjoyable and the online community is great. Just be prepar3d to wait an age for new stuff and pay through your ♥♥♥ for it when it finally arrives (the game + all DLC on Steam will set you back over £500. More if you include what's not featured on Steam and accessible via the Eagle Dev DCS standalone).

content:
er 21, 2016
												A true flight sim for any pilot enthusiest, especially if you are considering a military career. this isn't a game that u just jump into and expect to start flying. you need a basic understanding of flight instruments. if u get an add-on with a clickable cockpit, you will have to spend hours going through the training courses just to know how to start and operate the aircraft systems. you really cannot claim to master any aircraft without putting at least the standard of 40 flight hours into each aircraft. The sense of accomplishment as u struggle with one apect, then turn it into an easy task, is what keeps me playing. When u get that perfect 3-point touchdown with the p-51, then start doing it over and over, u really feel like its a major acheivement. At this point, i only have 50 hours on the game, and i still feel like a noob. im very confident with the p-51 now and ill be going into the A-10 add-on next. As to physics, i cannot say whether they are absolutely realistic or not, but i am highly impressed. If u put the time into the game and really try to learn how to fly, thats when u get the entertainment factor out of it. It greatly helps to buy a dlc with clickable cockpit also and i will tell any pilot enthusiest to get this game.

content:
5, 2015
												Absolutely the best flight experience available on the PC.Here are some considerations:-It is a *simulator,* don't expect an arcade experience, even in the simple flight modes.-Combat is very real, and therefore very difficult.  Success is very satisfying, but be willing to take the time to learn how to succeed.-Despite some reviews the platform is exceptionally stable and functional, but the user interface is not intuitive (that's to be expected considering the scope of the simulation).  Again, it will take some time to learn.-Multiplayer is super fun, but know that it's a session-based environment, not open world.-Some modules (aircraft) will offer more content and detail than others, so do a little research before you purchase, and only purchase aircraft you are genuinely interested in flying.If you're a fan of aviation simulations, patient, and willing to learn, you will thoroughly enjoy your experience with DCS world.

content:
er 1, 2016
												DCS World is a great hardcore combat flight sim with a crazy amount of detail and I love it for that but something about the game doesn't feel the same as IL-2 1946 or Strike Fighters 2. I think it comes down to a few things with me. 1: Content is lacking. Compaired to IL-2 and SF2 the game feels a little barebones with its selection of aircraft. Yes the detail is much higher in DCS but I would rather see Eagle Dynamics come out with more playable aircraft if it means dropping the detail to that of FC3.2: No middle ground. Its full sim or nothing in DCS and thats fine but TBH I like the way IL-2 and SF2 handle sims and having the option just to set things as easy or as hard as I want. (sometimes i just want to blow s*** up) without going though the hassel. 3: Mod support. This leads back to the issue of not having a wide selection of aircraft in DCS and its far from having any type of mod Library that gets close to IL-2 or SF24: price of DLC. Now i'm no stranger to paying for DLC on a simulator (god knows I spent a lot in Train Simulator) but thats the thing. For me it comes down to "why pay when I can get a mod for SF2?" If they lowered the cost I wouldn't mind picking put more then what I have but at $50 I find it hard to justify getting one.DCS World is a great sim, but is it on my favorites list? no, It doesn't have the aircraft I like and it doesn't give me the same joy and gameplay experience that I look for in a sim.  7/10

content:
ry 19, 2014
												I am not an expert on flight simulators by any stretch of the imagination, so fair warning, I may be naive or ignorant in my assessment of this game. That said, by far I believe DCS World, and what I have seen of its addons including DCS: A-10C Warthog, to be the most comprehensive and realistic modern combat flight simulator series I have ever seen. Many thanks to the developers for making the base game available for free on Steam. There's a lot included in DCS World to appeal to both the hardcore flight simulation crowd and to educators.There are some minor omissions and simplifications from DCS World's default aircraft model, the Su-25, compared to its DLC packages in terms of the compexity of the cockpit's controls and graphical complexity, but what is available is so impressive to me I can't complain. Even this simplified model is more complex than many flight sims I've experienced in the past.It's a good sign that some of the original companies which designed aircraft featured in this series are assisting with the development of the game/simulator, alongside the usual industry veterans. The sound design, user interface design, controls, mission editor and scripting system all seem to be quite well-executed. The game supports flightsticks, HOTAS and TrackIR, as well as (a rather inappropriate method of control in my opinion) the Microsoft Xbox 360 Controller alongside a mouse and keyboard.I've not yet completely explored what the game has to offer in terms of difficulty levels, or rather, aircraft simulation settings, but my advice is that people who are looking for a casual, pick-up-and-go flight simulator should do their research or probably look elsewhere, as the game may be far more complex than expected. That said, you can't beat the price, so I would insist that you test the game out and see what you think of it first. There's plenty of tutorials in-game as well as available on the Internet to help you become accustomed to the Su-25's basic startup/taxi/takeoff/landing procedures and usage in combat.If you are interested in online multiplayer, there is a thriving community of DCS World players online these days. I bet there's a wingman available to help you out.Overall, at a first impression I consider DCS World and its expansions to be an excellent value for its cost. I look forward to buying the expansions.

												Hello, this is my DCS World Review ^-^Before I get started, I am a huge jet and ww2 aircraft fanThis game puts my Knowledge of aircraft to shamePros:Super realistic damage and flight modelsActive playersBeautiful graphics (even on low, as my computer isn't the best I run it on low)Updated oftenLegendary planes such as the Bf 109, P-51, Fw 190, F-86, MiG-15bis, MiG-21, and even the F-15Cons: Optimization could be betterVery steep learning curveConfusing tutorialsPrices for extra aircraft are very expensivePull 1G in the Su25 "Frogfoot" and get complained at in Russian Requires lots of patience, time and effortPractically requires a joystickAll in all, amazing game, if you've got a beast computer, I highly recommend this game!9/10 would rip my wings and catch fire immediately in a Tf-51 (P51D ground attack variant)

content:
er 29, 2016
												Where to begin....I've owned this game since the beginning. Loved Flaming Cliffs, etc..bought Blachshark when it came out. Very difficult, steep learning curve and I played it here and there, then I got an Oculus Rift and everything changed.....Suddenly I'm sitting in the cockpit of these planes looking around, these that I've dreamed of flying, looking at pictures as a kid (there where naked girls too but I've always loved stuff that flies). Now I can't get enough and I've got several of the planes figured out. What a difference a nice VR headset makes.My only ctriticism of DCS is the trainging missions aren't consistent. Some are great and narrated like the A10, others are not narrated, one set is narrated in Russian (maybe I have a head start for when trump sells us to Russia?), it has English text at least. I noticed also in some training missions, mapped controls don't line up with the directions. I've been able to work around it all. It just feels like they all should run through a scrubbing/standardization process before it's released.That said I can't get enough, steep learning curve warning though, it's very realistic. Tons of hours and I still rarely get through a mission end to end without crashing.

content:
5, 2015
												Hello,this game is a piece of art. Some say it is the best mil avio sim there is out there. Even with its free module you will find yourself capapble of doing many tasks and missions (using the wide weaponary). But don't think you will be able to hop in the game and start doing all the ace manuevers and tactics. You will have to put your mind to it and approach it with the atitude of learning new stuff. Game is in no mean necessary to be played as if you are a real pilot. You can take it casualy, but you will still need to take notes and be patient. The feeling of reward after succeding is huge. After you master the Frog, you can try out some of the other modules and see what suits you. You might be a Ground pounder or a Fighter guy. Or maybe a rotor head ? You can go back and fly some of the older gen planes as well. New modules are being brought out often.Some tips I have are:- Take notes !!!! - Get a Stick (even a cheaper one)- get yourself a headtracker (TrackIR, Facetrack(homemade TrackIR)- As much as you all love steam, I recommend getting the standalone game as you will be able to use all the avaliable mods on the forums (terrain, texture, sound, liveries) - register on the forums so you can see what new content there is from the community ( mods, screens, vids, news and projects) http://forums.eagle.ru/- if you are using a single monitor I recommend playing the game in Windowed mode(it is borderles so you wont see a diff) as it allows you to alt+tab a lot easier without any issues    And last but not in meaning. If you ever have time, check out the mission editor tool. It is a powerful tool where you can unleash all the imaginary missions you ever had. Has lurning curve as anything in this game.I've been flying the A-10C for 3 years(nearly 4) now and F-15C for year and a half and I am happy with the amount of time I've inversted in this. Don't be scared that you won't be able to do something or it is too complicated. No such thing. If anyone wans help or tips for those two modules I could help out :) cheers and see you in the sky. Shoutout to the 104th server, the best pvp server !P.S: If you wonder why I have so low game time. It is because I play the standalone version. I downloaded the game on steam just so I can write this review.Don't be scared to ask me any questions about the A-10C and F-15C

												I have never in my life been as challenged in playing a game as i have in this one. At times it feels like you can't do something or that a city is simply too well defended by SAMs. And just when you feel as though you are defeated and can no longer complete your mission, you decide to ask for some help. and everyone is extremely helpful. It doesnt matter if you are a vet or a new pilot people always help out and (almost) never put others down. I love this game with a passion. The fact that the aircraft are 1:1 replicas including flight models is amazing! There is a plane for every job and no 1 plane can do it all, it truly is a team effort to win. I give this game a solid 10/10!

content:
29, 2014
												DCS has a steep learning curve, however the large international community behind it fills the void with tutorials, campaigns guides. Eagle Dynamics have continued to lead the way in Flight Simulators in the void left behind by Microsoft and Jane's, with DCS World providing different Planes, Helicopters and Strategy modules through affordable DLC with Campaign and Mission Editors to prolong gameplay.While the Visuals are impressive and the controls are reasonable quick to grasp, the game is very unforgiving. Many hours need to be put in to master combat flight, as quite often new players to Eagle Dynamics' games will be destroyed by the AI before they can even see them. This can lead players to become frustrated, so I do recommend those who wish to play this game watch some tutorials and practice against Harmless targets before trying against Hostiles.I do recommend this game, but I have to admit I got very frustrated with Air to Air combat, so Air to Ground will prove less challenging for newcomers.6.5/10

												Aesomely realistic. You can't get more fun out of a modern day flight simulator than this. Although the multiplayer doesn't have the biggest community, it's still a blast, and really, watching your missile blast an enemy aircraft apart is simply . . . awesome.The free version with the Su-25T attack jet is fun, and if you can pick up Flaming Cliffs 3, well you're all set. Fighter jets make DCS way more fun.The fighters are quite realistic, even if DCS only calls FC3 a "mid-fidelity" sim. The F-15C, Su-27 and Su-33 Flanker are a blast to fly. Launching missiles from over 10nm away from the E/A is just so satifying, especially for a veteran of WWII sims. Speaking of WWII sims, DCS is releasing DCS: WWII soon, starting with the Fw-190 D-9 this August, and adding the Bf 109 K-4, Spitfire Mk. IX, and P-47D soon after. The WWII Normandy theatre map is getting released in Q1 2015.Download this sim, and remember, the additional modules are all the fun.

content:
ry 23, 2014
												DCS world is a great sim. However it does have a huge learning curve, for those who like the hard core sim where every buttion and switch is modeled in the aircraft look no further! lucky for people who aren't so hard core there is the Flaming cliffs 3 module although this module still takes a bit to figure out how to use the planes some you tube vids and some button mapping to a good quality joystick and dogfighting is a blast! FC3 adds the f15C, su-27, these planes are pretty easy to fly (you dont have to pull 20 switches to fire a cannon). After playing a bit in FC3 and finally getting the hang of radar and beyond vis fighting I found DCS FC3 to be and enjoyable and challanging sim, dodging Heat seekers by dropping flares and pulling hard 7-9G turns only to have the missile pass beneath the belly of the aircraft by a factor of meters is such a rush, and then winning your first airvictory and then your first combat sortie is somthing that instills a sort of pride in you.TL;DR: DCS world modules like A-10C,BLACK SHARK 2, and other stand alone planes are more suited to the hard core players (even though there is a game mode it's not very well explained) FC3 with a small amount of learning can be a rewarding and fun module for the Sim junkie. (ps look up youtube tutorials as they tend to explain how to use the systems better i found this one helped alot with the F-15

content:
1, 2014
												This game is a kind of simulation of airplanes. You are able to fly certain planes in a simulated environment in military missions. There are many planes available though most are extra dlc's, you only get the soviet SU-25T for free, which is still very fun to play. Generally you should have a joystick with thrust and use either TrackIR or something like FaceTrackNoIR to control your head movement in the cockpit. Also important to mention is that the different dlc's (also called modules) with their planes have different simulation difficulty, some have a non-clickable 3D cockpit with simplyfied flight model and some like the A-10C require you to basically learn how to start up and fly the plane in a way you would do in reality with all it's buttons, switches and so on. Overall it is a great game, not the most accesible but the free plane is great to explore whether you like this game and you can always decide to go more hardcore with other planes or difficult missions. Aaaaand you also get the free mission editor/campaign editor which allows you to create your own content. So all summed up, you like flight simulation and fighting jets? Try this, it's nice.

4, 2013
												Hands down the best flight sim around. If you have ever thought about wanting to fly a plane or helo, this is as real as it gets. This Sim will take time to master but it is all worth it in the end. The SU-25T Frogfoot is a great starter plane with simplified inputs. If you are looking for something a little more complicated the A-10C, Black Shark 2, MI-8, UH-1H and P-51 allow you to touch every button in the cockpit. I would highly recommend all of them.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 24, 2015
												Okay two caveats that need to be addressed right off the bat:1)This game that you are downloading is module-based. So all you get from the free download is the P-51 and Su-25. Fun, but not super content-rich,2)Do not buy this game if you want to jump in a cockpit and go blastin'. You will be disappointed.Aside from that, I love this game. I was a big Ace Combat fan as a kid and always wanted something more technically challenging. It did take me a few months to gain a firm grasp of the controls, mission editor and combat tactics, but if you want to pretend to be a real fighter pilot, this is the one. Who knew trapping on a carrier or just even successfully flying a CAP would be so fun? Tons of official (Nevada map coming next month) and user made content (lockonfiles) and a really fun mission editor. Where else can you attack a US Navy carrier group with an armada of Backfire bombers and simulate how that would really happen? Plus, the first time you spot a target, evade his missile in a cloud of flares, then bang a Sidewinder or R-73 up his tailpipe is just really something.tl;dr- Its a bit of a serious game (DCS is to other combat flight sims what ArmA III is to most tactical shooters. Its hard to figure out), but the level of realism and authenticity is unmatched.10/10 real (fake) pilots only

content:
1, 2015
												Having played FSX I first tried DCS World not expecting much difference. I was wrong. The learning curve is HUGE!!! Whereas in FSX I was able to figure out the throttle controls and a few basic commands then off I went, DCS requires patience, commitment and above all else a sense of humour.Whereas I was apparently able to fly a Boeing 747 within minutes on FSX, on DCS Black Shark it took me two hours of youtube tutuorials and mouse clicking to figure out how to get the engines of the KA-50 started and get the rotors going, then I got two inches off the ground and crashed the bloody thing! The graphics and feel of the game are both superior to FSX and there are tonnes of youtube vidoes on how to get the various aircraft started and fire the weapons (which isn't a case of "just pull the trigger") and you feel like to have learnt something when you finally get the Su-25T to take off without nose diving seconds later. I have gone from the basic DCS World to now owning the Flaming Cliffs 3, MiG-21 and Ka-50 Black Shark modules and am looking forward to purchasing the L-39 when it come out.

content:
10, 2015
												DCS: World is definitely an amazing simulator. It by far outclasses others due to excellent flight models, a multiplayer that makes sense, easy-to-learn mission editor, and a large amount of detail. Even Flaming Cliffs 3 aircraft have more detail than something like War Thunder.Actually, DCS excels at detail; for instance, the A-10C. It is the epitome of PC-based simulators, with most if not all of the real plane's functionality and flight characteristics. Another example is the Ka-50, and really any of the rotorcraft. They basically are the best in their class, with the full range of aerodynamic effects you'd get from the real thing- retreating blade stall, translational lift, "oh ♥♥♥♥ my blades just up and left me" (hopefully not IRL), etc. Another thing is Nevada Test and Training Range. It is a huge map; most of Nevada, in fact. Even some parts of California. The entire Las Vegas city and suburbs are present and amazing. Even though it's not out for steam yet (as of updating), I'll leave this here.

ber 17, 2015
												Love DCS. Unfortunately I don't have TrackIR or an Oculus Rift DK2 so I feel I'm missing out on a bit of the immersion. Logitech Wingman Extreme 3d Pro joystick does me but having to enable the joystick config file every single time I play is annoying.Flaming Cliffs and what it does needs more of an explanation as I ended up buying F-15 AND flaming cliffs which was a waste. I've bought the enhanced versions of both A-10 and Blackshark 2 which are fantasticly authentic with cockpit buttons.I would love to see more British aircraft and helicopters... in particular WWII aircraft like the Spitfire and Harrier.Tornado and Jaguar ... and of course the AH-64 Apache Gunship which I'm told was scrapped as module because the team responsible were making the E variant which is currently still in service and classified... they were told to drop it.I'd be happy with the D variant rather than a mod skin over the Blackshark 2 which doesn't really do it for me.Waiting with baited breath for the Hawk module to drop in price on steam as I've paid enough and I'm not forking out another £25+ to fly a Hawk.Can't wait for DCS2 and DX12 graphics. My pc is upgraded and ready to go for it.

												Disclaimer - non steam user, transitioned to Eagle Dynamics own version a long time ago. Hours are far from correct.I'm far from a stranger to flight sims and I have tried pretty much every sim worth checking out. And I have to say that DCS outshines pretty much every competitor! If you're a flight geek this pretty much is a must for you.There's something with this game that speaks to me in so many ways.  From flying a CAP in the F-15 or the brand new Mirage 2000c, going in for a gun run with the Hog, hugging the ground with Huey or simply making a nice vfr in the L39.Yes it's hard in the begining, yes it takes sometime to learn but the sense of accomplishment you get from this is hard to find anywhere else.I can't express enough how good of an experience this game really is! The only complaint I might have had with this game would have been the slightly dated graphics. But with the release of  (the FREE) DCS 2 that complaint is gone.

												This is an amzing experience. YOu can really feel like you have flown an aircraft. Luckily there is a GAME mode if you dont want to spend hours learning how to really fly, but if you do, you can.I personally dont want to yet, but maybe in the future... you never know.It really does push the graphics though, and my brand new, bought for VIVE, 980 struggles above medium graphics. I spent a full day in a multimillion pound British Army simulator, and the VIVE experience on DCS is better!If you just want to fly around, make sure you go into the settings and find the options for GAMEPLAY and choose GAME.This is an awesome programme, without a doubt, and the marriage with VR is made in heaven.

content:
y 10, 2016
												   Doubtlessly, the best military aircraft simulation, no pros and cons here. If youre looking for the best experience with crafts like A-10, SU-25, MIGs, F-15, others, + variety of choppers - it's your choice. Specifically For F-18, F-16, F-14 look elsewhere, VRS things for Flight Simulator X, falcon BMS and others.   MUST HAVE, before even thinking of purchasing this one:- TrackIR (absolute MUST);- joystick and throttle (best if Thrustmaster H.O.T.A.S);- rudder pedals (many would argue,  but thats a MUST, cuz you'll never get to use wheel brakes and yaw axis correctly  with else);- capable PC (stronger the better cuz performance in this is a question of life and death sometimes);- touchscreen monitor as wide and big as possible (optional, but VERY recommended, rids you of constant mouse  usage. anoying when right hand always on stick then mouse then back);- voice recognition softwere and mic (useful for issuing radio comands and requests) - persistence and patience;Expences are high, and be ready for it. Be ready to spend hours, months and years learning and practising everything, and youll be very surprised of the result, it's like nothing else in PC gaming on my experience. Its not even a game, sometimes it's a hard brain work but that very rewarding when the mission is 100 % complete

content:
er 13, 2015
												If you want to feel like a real pilot, but you financialy or phisically  can't afford to be a pilot in real life, than this is the game for you.Years ago I played Lock On - Mondern Air Combat and one day I thought, wouldn't it be awesome if there would be a game with these awesome grapics and realism and they made the cockpit fully clickable like in Falcon 4 Allied Force wich I played at the time too. They must have read my mind, because a couple of years later, this game showed up. Back then it was Black Shark (World and helo in one, later they sepperated everything).This game is  awesome and relatively perfect. This comming from a man that would love to fly a jet in real life. DCS World is free and comes with one non fully clickable cockpit SU-25T. The rest of the modules, wich holds one fully clickable cockpit aircraft, you need to buy sepperately. This is kind of ideal. Why? Because you don't have to buy the airplanes that are incrdibly ugly to you. If there is an airplane you absolutely love, buy ther module. If there is an airplane you absolutely hate, let it be and don't buy the module.  What I don't like is that the modules are so expensive. And with expensive I mean that every module, wich means one airplane or one new map, are all priced like a full, brand new, well liked and antissipated game. wich menas 50-60 euro's. No Idea what it would be in Dollars. The airplane modules I can understand, but a map? Well, that is a bit much in my opinion.However I do love the game very much. Beautifull graphics wich you don't see much in games. Super realistic aircraft where you have to use the cockpit buttons to set up weapons, navigation systems, radio's etc. This is the game for all of us who can never realize our dreams of becomming real pilots.

content:
29, 2015
												DCS is an amazing game if you have the patience and mental capacity to learn and remember all of the systems and how to use them on the specific aircraft that you want to fly, and once you do this, it'll be implanted into your mind and you'll have fun. If you want to get into air-to-air engagments, then go for the F-15C. If you want to get in to air-to-ground engagments, then go for the A-10A, but if you wan to fly a plane almost exactly as it is flown in real life, then go for the A-10C. The main difference in modules like the A-10C and the F-15C (besides them being two completely different aircraft) is the interactive cockpit. This means that the A-10C has a cockpit with buttons that are almost all clickable and all carry out the same function as the real life counterpart. Other than that the modules all have the same realism level meaning that they handle and behave very realistically both in combat and free flight missions.I give this game a 9.5/10 rating because you have a somewhat limited selection of planes to fly, but this isn't an immediate problem because by the time you learn how to utilize a plane's capabilities effectively in combat,  you won't want to instantly jump into another because you probably won't be interested in making yourself commit suicide.Warning:DCS is not a game, it's a simulator. You can't just load it up and play with no learning period. If you want a game like that, then play Ace Combat. This game is very serious, so don't think you'll be the one to just hop on and instantly be good at it, because if you do, you'll loose all confidence you had in yourself as a gamer.

content:
er 6, 2015
												Ok where to begin, I am coming from a previous warthunder standpoint with near 300+ hours on there if you add the time before I had it on steam. This was a huge learning curve from the arcade and realistic battles of warthunder but it was made easier from my time with the older sims such as Apache vs Havoc, Commanche vs Hokum and Mig alley all really old games but sims nontheless. I love this game already, it has aircraft I really wanted to fly and although the graphics show their age it is a wonderful sim, A Joystick is a must in this game as well as TrackIr which I am jerryrigging up as we speak. Now for those who say you cannot get into combat easily or whine that it's too hard just do all the training missions twice, grab a friend and make a custom mission with low threats (watch a tutorial on how to make a mission it is easier when the buttons make sense) and fart around for a few hours. I personally went from being whaaaaat when I started to hey all this makes sense and now I can take out 80% of the things I fire at in under 4 hours of playing this game. As of right now I am waiting for funds to get Flaming cliffs due to the volume of aircraft it gives and then combined arms. So if you are looking at this game do give it a try the learning curve may be steep but I have had fun figuring it out. And if graphics are an issue for you check back in a few months because update 2.0 will be bringing graphics equal to Arma 3 which will make this thee best combat aviation (and ground forces in combined arms) sim out there all way round.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
2016
DCS World is flight simulator first and throughout with a steep learning curve. However its free-to-play model does make it accessible to trying it before investing in expensive add-ons. Performance and PlayabilityPerformance wise the game runs really well on my medium-high machine, was able to easily max out most of the settings and with no obvious issues, and it can be quite visually nice to look at. The game also runs without issue on Windows 10 for me.


Su-25T at sunset 
A Screenshot of DCS World
By: Vetron




AircraftThe game comes with two aircraft; a TF-51D "Mustang" WW2 Fighter, and a Su-25T "Frogfoot" Attack Jet. Both are modeled with considerable detail and offer realistic flight models. The aircraft can be modified with different payload / weapon options. Aircraft addons you buy may offer even more realistic flight behavior depending on what you buy.


Su-25T Cockpit 
A Screenshot of DCS World
By: Vetron




NOTE: Because this game caters towards relatively hardcore flight mechanics,  I would recommend if you are a new pilot to flight simulation (i.e. never flown at all in other simulators) start out with more accessible titles (such as Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition[ http] or X-Plane 10 Global[ http] as of writing this) until you have the grasp of the very basics of flight, and then come back and work through the training missions included. Jumping right in might just lead to frustration if you don’t really have a handle on the basics of flight, as its easier to learn from the point of how to fly the specific aircraft, rather than how to fly a plane in general. At least in my opinion anyway (and no means a dig at the game).Free to play limitsThere are no obvious limits or restrictions in place that I could see. You are really only limited by what aircraft you can fly, most of which you have to purchase separate.Free Flight (Instant Action and Fast Missions)DCS World comes with both pre-set instant action scenarios, as well as fast missions. The fast missions allow you to select the aircraft you wish to fly, then set the start location and enemy difficulty – and generate a combat scenario where you can put your aircraft to the test. 


Su-25T downing an A-10 
A Screenshot of DCS World
By: Vetron




Missions & CampaignIncluded with the free-to-play portion of the game is several stand-alone missions for the SU-25T, as-well as a scripted campaign. There is also several training missions as-well. There is likely several hours’ worth here, and you can of course just install user created missions or create your own. ConclusionIf you want a combat flight simulator, with emphasis on the simulation then the free-to-play DCS World is recommended.GoodPair of detailed aircraft (with many more to buy)Realistic Flight modelsSelection of available missions and campaignFree-to-playNot so goodNot as wide selection of content as other gamesLimited scenery

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 18
												Being a long time flight simmer I'm really happy about how DCS world brings flight and air combat to our PC screens. Great Flight sim with a lot of attention to detail. The world is beautifully rendered with lots of, hills, valleys, towns, cities, rivers and thousands of trees all over the landscape. Aircraft are beatutifully rendered inside and out, they sound thunderous and the flight physics feel pretty accurate to me. Mind you, to my disgust I've never had the chance to fly around like a excited wide eyed lunatic in an F-15 or an A-10 but aircraft feel responsive to a host of factors in the air from cross winds, to the weight of your loadout, temperature, altitude etc. Honestly a lot of the time I have a great time just flying around enjoying the sensation of flight. 


YouTube™ Video: DCS World: F-15c Flathatter 

			Views: 101		

			Flathatting: An unauthorized low level flight. Terrorizing the locals free flying in the F-15c...with some roadtunes.		

This sim does have a pretty steep learning curve and will take some time to learn each aircraft and it's systems. Modules can be expensive but its best you chose an aircraft you want to learn and master it as each aircraft functions fundamentaly differnt. I would treat each full price module has it's own simulator. There are cheaper modules available as well that are not as expensive or as detailed that will still give you a pretty awesome flying experience for a fraction of the price. I will definatly say that this is not a casual game. I see lots of reviews from people saying wtf I coudln't even make it off the ground etc etc. Its really recommended you RTFM or seek out some tutorials. I would also recommend some form of HOTAS setup for the best experience. More content is being added frequently, I'm particulary looking forward to DCS 2.0 going live, which includes Las Vegas / Nellis AFB and red flag campaigns, as well as the addition to the release of the F/A-18.Lastly, performance wise DCS is pretty CPU intensive. If you have a decent CPU, you will certainly get better performance. Though some easy ways to boost performance is to decrease water detail and civillion traffic ( streets are populated with scores of moving vehicles and trains) There are also guides out there for other ways to tweak performance.

content:
8, 2016
												So I spend some time in the tutorials figuring out the controls, then load up the "Dogfight" mission. 1 SU-25 vs 2 A-10s? Sounds like fun.Attempt the first:I fire both Aphids head on, both track for flares. We pass each other and start to turn, and it is at this point that the Ace Combat reflexes that loom threateningly in the dark corners of my mind whenever I boot up a flight sim decide to pounce. I forget that I am flying an SU-25, not an SU-37, and attempt to execute a j-turn. It goes poorly. (For details on exactly how poorly it went, see the verse about the passenger liner from the song "Albuquerque" by Weird Al Yankovick.)Attempt the second:I fail to achieve missile lock during the first pass and circle around. We mauever for a while, I manage to tag one of the Warthogs with my first Archer and kill it with the second. I manage to get behind the second Warthog and fire both Aphids. Both go for his flares. I close to gun range and we enter the horizontal scissors. I take a snapshot and miss just before I overshoot. I hear him fire his gun, and dive to try and evade. Several seconds later I notice two rather peculiar and alarming things: A, my plane has decided that it wants to be upside down now and wont take no for an answer, and B, I can't pull out of the dive. Approximately 3.72 seconds before I make an impressively large mess in some poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥'s wheat field, I look behind me and notice that roughly two thirds of my plane have mysteriously vanished.10/10 Would fail to notice getting lit up with a GAU-8 all over again.

content:
1, 2016
												DCS World + A-10C + Flaming Cliffs 3Yes, this game is worth the money. I got the A-10C first in 2011 but I never really got into it. It wasn't until Dec or Jan when I really started flying. The hardest part about this game is trying to figure out what you need to bind to your joystick in order to not just fly but be affective at bombing or dogfighting and what not else. After that youtube and Eagle Forums are you best friends. Flaming cliffs came shortly after I became proficient in the A-10. I felt like I needed something fast to fly and when you can mod aircraft like the F-14, F-18, A-7, F-4, and the F-16 into the game using fc3 aircraft as a cockpit base, it really adds to the worth. Since DCS has a large ammount of AI aircraft with accurate flight models, modding these into the game is more than flying an F-15 skinned to look like something else. Be sure to check it out.

content:
, 2016
												Im new to the flight sim game and also new (as many people are) to Virtual Reality, with this being said I have played a few games on the HTC Vive (which is what i play this game on)Im prone to motion sickness in games, first noticed years ago on the game "doom". but i didnt really get the motion sickness from this game.I loaded up DCS World not expecting to much and was instantly blow away by the cockpit detail and the realism of it all, i remember just looking out at he wing and engine of the plane and i felt like I was on a real plane, i haven't been in a fighter plane but i have flown in commercial airlines.There is a hell of alot of keys, for example: to start each engine, air brakes, wheel brakes, wing extenders which you can see on the cockpit dials change as you use the keyboard to apply each item. For me maybe because i dont have a joystick and was flying via the cursor keys, this was the only down side to the game as i had to lift the Vive head set off my face to see the key to press which when your trying to land the plane was a real pain and led to many crashes.If the VIVE controllers worked and you could grap the the joystick to steer the plane and push the cockpit dials to lower wheels, apply brakes etc this would be awesome.

												Home-Made Enchiladas3 tablespoons vegetable oil1 1/2 pounds skinless boneless chicken breastSalt and pepper2 teaspoons cumin powder2 teaspoons garlic powder1 teaspoon Mexican Spice Blend1 red onion, chopped2 cloves garlic, minced1 cup frozen corn, thawed5 canned whole green chiles, seeded and coarsely chopped4 canned chipotle chiles, seeded and minced1 (28-ounce) can stewed tomatoes1/2 teaspoon all-purpose flour16 corn tortillas1 1/2 cups enchilada sauce, canned1 cup shredded Cheddar and Jack cheesesGarnish: chopped cilantro leaves, chopped scallions, sour cream, chopped tomatoesDirectionsCoat large saute pan with oil. Season chicken with salt and pepper. Brown chicken over medium heat, allow 7 minutes each side or until no longer pink. Sprinkle chicken with cumin, garlic powder and Mexican spices before turning. Remove chicken to a platter, allow to cool.Saute onion and garlic in chicken drippings until tender. Add corn and chiles. Stir well to combine. Add canned tomatoes, saute 1 minute.Pull chicken breasts apart by hand into shredded strips. Add shredded chicken to saute pan, combine with vegetables. Dust the mixture with flour to help set.Microwave tortillas on high for 30 seconds. This softens them and makes them more pliable. Coat the bottom of 2 (13 by 9-inch) pans with a ladle of enchilada sauce. Using a large shallow bowl, dip each tortilla in enchilada sauce to lightly coat. Spoon 1/4 cup chicken mixture in each tortilla. Fold over filling, place 8 enchiladas in each pan with seam side down. Top with remaining enchilada sauce and cheese.Bake for 15 minutes in a preheated 350 degree F oven until cheese melts. Garnish with cilantro, scallion, sour cream and chopped tomatoes before serving. Serve with Spanish rice and beans.

												Only for aircraft enthusiasts. In the military genre, this is the most hardcore sim there is. Be prepared to invest weeks in learning and mastering an aircraft, anywhere from a start-up procedure, to weapon employment, to a successful landing. All that barely scratches the surface though. Flight maneuvers, countermeasures, situational awareness, and understanding enemy capabilities is imperative.The Caucasus map is free and you simply purchase the modules that interest you. Continuous upgrades and dev support is present. New maps and aircrafts are always in production. There's something for everyone included in this sim.
